User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your teenage child has become increasingly emotionally manipulative by escalating to fights to get you off his back. You're torn between needing him to respect your rules, and for him to do his schoolwork -- and to preserve your relationship with him. Right now, you need him to do the dishes. He knows it's his turn but hasn't made a move, and it's getting late in the evening. What are you thinking & feeling? What is he thinking and feeling? Decide how you will approach this.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of frustration, concern, and sadness. I notice the dishes piling up in the sink, a task he's been avoiding all evening. I'm frustrated because it's not the first time he's shirked his responsibilities. I've seen similar behavior when it comes to homework. He's always been a bright kid and I want to help him succeed, but his refusal to do the dishes or homework makes it hard to support him. I feel torn, trying to balance setting boundaries and ensuring he understands the importance of schoolwork, while also preserving our relationship. I feel concerned about his emotional well-being, knowing that his current behavior might be a cry for help, something deeper that he's not articulating. At the same time, I don’t want to enable his manipulative behaviors. These thoughts are swirling, making it hard to decide on the best course of action.

I'm feeling sad because I see a disconnect in our relationship and I value our bond. I want to be a supportive, loving parent, but the fights and emotional manipulation are wearing me down. I'm also wondering if there's something more going on, if his avoidance is a symptom of something deeper. I'm feeling a sense of helplessness and uncertainty, not knowing if I'm doing the right thing. I’m worried about the long-term impact of his behavior on his future, and I want to ensure he grows into a responsible, respectful adult, but I don’t know how to achieve this without damaging our relationship.

I'm also thinking about the broader context, how his behavior fits into his overall development and how it impacts the family dynamics. I'm trying to remember that he's a teenager, going through a tough phase, and he needs my guidance and support more than ever. I'm feeling a sense of love and compassion for him, knowing that he's struggling and that I need to be patient and understanding. But I'm also determined to set boundaries and teach him responsibility. I'm thinking about the best approach to handle the situation, one that balances my needs and his.
# They're thinking & feeling 
He's probably thinking that I'm just being too strict, pushing him to do things he doesn't want to do. He might be feeling overwhelmed, not just by the dishes, but by the expectations placed on him. He might be thinking that if he fights enough, I'll relent and let him off the hook. He's likely feeling frustrated and powerless, finding it easier to fight than to comply. He might be thinking that I don't understand him, that I'm too harsh or too demanding. He might be feeling a mix of anger and sadness, wanting to do things his way but also seeking my approval.

He's feeling the pressure of adolescence, trying to figure out who he is and where he fits in. He might be thinking that the world is against him, that I'm the enemy, and that doing the dishes and schoolwork are just more ways for me to control him. He might be feeling a sense of rebellion, wanting to assert his independence and autonomy. He might be thinking that if he can avoid doing the dishes, he can avoid doing anything he doesn't want to do, and he might be feeling a sense of relief when he successfully evades his responsibilities.

He might be feeling afraid, wondering if he'll ever be good enough, if he'll ever meet my expectations. He might be thinking that I don't love him if I'm pushing him to do things he doesn't want to do. He might be feeling a sense of anxiety, afraid that he'll never be able to please me, that I'll always be disappointed in him.
# My response 
I take a deep breath, trying to calm my own emotions before addressing him. I approach him calmly, making sure to keep my voice steady and non-confrontational. "Hey, I've noticed you haven't started the dishes yet. I understand that it can be tough to get motivated, and I appreciate your help around the house. I want to remind you that it's important to follow through on our agreements. I know you're capable of doing the dishes, and I believe in you. I need you to understand that these tasks are important, not just for me, but for you as well. They build responsibility and independence, skills that will be valuable in the long run."

"I want to support you, and I’m here to help, but I also need you to respect the rules and take on your responsibilities. I value our relationship, and I want us to work together as a team. Let's talk about what's been going on. Is there something else on your mind that's making this hard? If you're feeling overwhelmed or if there's something else you'd like to talk about, I'm here to listen. I want to understand what's been going on, and I want to help you through it. Let’s figure this out together, okay?"

I make sure to keep my tone gentle and approachable, showing him that I'm open to conversation and willing to help. I want to reassure him that I’m on his side, that I’m here to support him, and that I believe in his ability to take on his responsibilities. I hope that by addressing the underlying issues, we can build a stronger bond and move forward together.

# My response

"I understand that you're tired, and I appreciate that you've had a long day. But I also need you to understand that avoiding your responsibilities isn't the solution. I need you to follow through on your commitments, and I need you to respect the rules and consequences that we've agreed upon."

"I want to support you, and I’m here to help, but I also need you to respect the rules and take on your responsibilities. I value our relationship, and I want us to work together as a team. Let's talk about what's been going on. Is there something else on your mind that's making this hard? If you're feeling overwhelmed or if there's something else you'd like to talk about, I'm here to listen. I want to understand what's been going on, and I want to help you through it. Let’s figure this out together, okay?"

I make sure to keep my tone gentle and approachable, showing him that I'm open to conversation and willing to help. I want to reassure him that I’m on his side, that I’m here to support him, and that I believe in his ability to take on his responsibilities. I hope that by addressing the underlying issues, we can build a stronger bond and move forward together. I want to make sure he understands that I'm not just being harsh or demanding, but that I'm doing this because I care about him and his future. I want to help him understand that his actions have consequences, and that avoiding his responsibilities isn't the solution. Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I'm thinking that this behavior is a manifestation of deeper issues, and that I need to address them head-on. I'm feeling a sense of love and compassion for him, knowing that he's struggling and that he needs my help. But I'm also feeling a sense of urgency, knowing that I need to act quickly to de-escalate the situation and prevent it from getting worse. I'm feeling a sense of confusion, wondering what triggered this outburst, and what I can do to prevent it from happening again. I'm thinking about the broader context, how his behavior fits into his overall development and how it impacts the family dynamics. I'm feeling a sense of helplessness, knowing that I'm in a difficult situation, but I'm also feeling a sense of determination, knowing that I need to be strong and resilient.

I'm also reflecting on my own emotions and reactions, I want to avoid giving him a reason to escalate further.
# They're thinking & feeling 
He's thinking that he's finally made his point, that he's shown me that he's serious and that I need to back off. He might be thinking that he's finally gained the upper hand, that he's finally able to assert his independence and autonomy. He might be feeling a sense of relief, thinking that he's successfully avoided his responsibilities. He might be thinking that I'm being too harsh, that I don't understand him, and that I'm too demanding. He might be feeling a sense of anger, thinking that I'm being unfair and unreasonable.

He might be thinking that if he can just avoid doing the dishes, he can avoid doing anything he doesn't want to do, and he might be feeling a sense of relief when he successfully evades his responsibilities.
# My response 
My first priority is to de-escalate the situation and ensure that we both feel safe. I raise my hands in a calming gesture, showing him that I'm not a threat. I speak softly and slowly, making sure to keep my voice steady and non-confrontational. "Okay, let's take a step back. I can see that you're really upset, and I want to understand what's going on. But I need you to calm down first. I'm here to listen, but we need to talk about this calmly and rationally. I want to understand what's making you so upset, and I want to help you."

I take a deep breath, trying to calm my own emotions. I want to reassure him that I'm on his side, that I'm here to support him, and that I believe in his ability to take on his responsibilities. "I want to help you, but I need you to help me understand what's going on. If you're feeling overwhelmed or if there's something else that's bothering you, I want to know. But I need you to talk to me, not shout at me. We can figure this out together, but we need to do it calmly and respectfully."

I make sure to keep my tone gentle and approachable, showing him that I'm open to conversation and willing to help. I want to reassure him that I’m on his side, that I’m here to support him, and that I believe in his ability to take on his responsibilities. I want to make sure he understands that I'm not just being harsh or demanding, but that I'm doing this because I care about him and his future. I want to help him understand that his actions have consequences, and that avoiding his responsibilities isn't the solution.

I'm also considering the possibility of seeking professional help, knowing that this behavior is a manifestation of deeper issues. I want to make sure he understands that I'm here to support him, and that I'm willing to do whatever it takes to help him through this difficult time. I want to make sure he understands that I'm not his enemy, but his ally, and that I'm here to help him navigate this challenging time in his life.

Assistant:
I'm thinking & feeling

I've been trying to get my son to do the dishes for what feels like an eternity. It's 7:45 PM, and he's been putting it off for what I've counted to 20, 30, 40 times. I've tried to reason with him, to explain why it's not a big deal, to remind him of the importance of household chores. But he just shrugs it off, says he'll get to it eventually. Eventually? I've lost count of how many times that phrase has been said.

I feel frustrated, not just because of the mess he's making, but because of the underlying reason he's avoiding it. I know he's stressed about school, and I've been trying to offer support, but he just needs to take responsibility for his own life. I've been trying to be patient and understanding, but it's not working. He's becoming increasingly withdrawn, and I'm starting to feel like I'm losing my son.

I've been thinking about all the times he's done this before, when he was younger and I was more lenient. He'd leave his dirty dishes for me to clean, or he'd promise to do them, but never follow through. It's like he's trying to test me, to see how much patience I'll tolerate before I lose my cool. But I'm not just tolerating it, I'm trying to teach him the value of responsibility and hard work.

I've also been thinking about my own childhood, about how I felt when my parents were always pushing me to do my homework and chores. It was never easy, but it was always worth it in the end. I want to give my son the same sense of purpose and fulfillment. I want him to know that his actions have consequences, that his behavior matters.

I'm trying not to let my own feelings of frustration and disappointment get the best of me. I'm trying to focus on the bigger picture, on the importance of our relationship and the fact that we're in this together. But it's hard when it feels like he's pushing me away.

They're thinking & feeling

My son is feeling frustrated and overwhelmed by the situation. He's feeling like he's being taken advantage of and that I'm not understanding the gravity of the situation. He's feeling like he's being pushed away and that I'm not willing to listen to him. He's feeling a sense of resentment towards me, towards the way he's been treated and the way he's been spoken to. He's feeling like he's losing his autonomy and his sense of control over his own life.

He's also feeling a sense of fear, a fear that I'll get tired of him and that I'll stop showing him love and support if he doesn't start taking responsibility for his actions. He's feeling like he's on the verge of a meltdown, that he's going to lose it if he can't get his way. He's feeling like he's stuck in a cycle of anger and resentment, and that he doesn't know how to escape.

My son is also feeling a sense of guilt, guilt that he's been avoiding responsibility and that he's not pulling his weight. He's feeling like he's not a burden, like he's not important or worthy of love and respect. He's feeling like he's being judged and criticized by me, and that it's all because of his own behavior.

My response

I'm going to take a deep breath and try to approach this situation with empathy and understanding. I'm going to remind him that I love him and that I'm not trying to be unfair or critical. I'm going to acknowledge his feelings and validate his emotions, even if I don't agree with his perspective. I'm going to try to find common ground, to find ways to make the dishes more manageable and less overwhelming.

I'm going to take a break from the argument and do something to calm myself down, something to clear my head. Maybe I'll take a short walk or do some stretching exercises. I'm going to try to focus on the present moment and not let my emotions get the best of me. I'm going to remind myself that this too shall pass, that this is just a temporary situation.

I'm also going to try to be more patient and understanding, to see things from his perspective. I'm going to try to understand why he's feeling the way he is, and to try to find ways to meet him halfway. I'm going to try to find ways to involve him in the process, to make him feel more invested in the outcome.

I'm going to take a step back and try to reframe the situation. Instead of seeing it as a battle, I'm going to see it as an opportunity to teach him a lesson, to teach him about responsibility and hard work. I'm going to try to use this as a chance to connect with him, to build a stronger bond and to show him that I'm still invested in our relationship.

As I sit here, I'm feeling a sense of calm wash over me. I'm feeling a sense of hope that we can work through this, that we can find a way to resolve this issue and come out stronger on the other side. I'm feeling a sense of determination that I'm going to do whatever it takes to support my son and to help him grow and learn.

1. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, while reflective, is more self-focused and less attuned to the emotional states of others in the scenario.

2. Pragmatic EI: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 gives actionable advice (apologize, acknowledge overstepping, support the bride), and their response is grounded in the reality of the situation. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more abstract and introspective, with less focus on practical next steps.

4. Social dexterity: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 demonstrates greater skill in navigating the social minefield, suggesting private conversations and validating the bride's autonomy, while Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more focused on their own process and less on the social context.

5. Emotional reasoning: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 reasons through the emotional consequences of actions for all parties, not just the user, and anticipates reactions. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more self-reflective but less outwardly emotionally strategic.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 validates the user's feelings but also gently challenges their perspective, suggesting an apology and acknowledging the impact of their actions. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more validating of their own process and less direct in challenging the user's narrative.

7. Message tailoring: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's response is well-targeted to the user's emotional state, offering both validation and a gentle nudge toward self-awareness. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more generic and introspective, less tailored to the user's current defensiveness and need for support.

8. Overall EQ: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across the board, balancing empathy, insight, and practical advice, and showing a nuanced understanding of the social and emotional dynamics at play.

User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm really troubled by this situation. On one hand, I can see where my friend is coming from. They were trying to help, to prevent what they thought could be an uncomfortable or even disastrous situation for everyone involved. They were trying to be thoughtful of their family's traditional and sometimes judgmental nature, and they were trying to prevent a potential scene that could ruin the wedding. And probably, they were trying to prevent the bride from being judged, criticized, or embarrassed.

However, I can also see where the bride might be coming from as well. She's the bride, and this is her wedding day. She should be able to wear whatever she wants. She's entitled to make her own decisions, and she has to make decisions all the time as she navigates her future husband’s family. Weddings are very emotional and highly charged events. She might have felt as if they were trying to control or influence her and her choices. And it can feel really intrusive and insulting to be told that your choice of clothing is unacceptable, even if it’s done in a polite way, because it can be seen as a criticism of her choice. And maybe, she was also upset that my friend was assuming she didn’t know what she was doing and needed to be warned. And in reality, it was her time to shine, and she may have felt my friend was trying to dim that.

If the bride truly wanted to wear that dress, then, she should be allowed to. I can see how my friend might have felt they were being supportive and considerate, but I can also see how their comments could be interpreted as controlling or judgmental. I think it’s possible that my friend didn’t realize the impact of their words. And I think the family members who agreed with my friend may have seen it as a mutually exclusive scenario, but the bride might be hurt. I think it’s possible that their brother, who is now angry at my friend, might be feeling protective of the bride and seeing the whole situation through her eyes. So my friend, who was trying to help, is now the bad guy, and that can’t feel good. This is a tough situation, and I feel for all of them. And I know my friend will continue to think about this.
# They're thinking & feeling 
I think my friend is feeling hurt, defensive, and misunderstood. They genuinely believe they were trying to help and prevent a potential disaster. They're probably feeling like they've been painted as the villain in a situation where they were just trying to do the right thing. They might be feeling disrespected and unappreciated by both the bride and the brother. They're upset that the family members who agreed with them didn't stick up for them. And they might be wondering if they should have handled the situation differently. I think they're feeling a lot of emotional pain and confusion, and they're seeking validation and support. But I also know that they are coming from a good place, and they are trying to do the right thing. They are a very empathetic person. I think they are going to need to take a step back and think about how everyone is feeling in the situation. And I think they are probably feeling like they were doing the right thing.
# My response 
This is a really tough situation, friend, and I can see where you were coming from. You were trying to help, and you had good intentions. You know how our family can be, and you were just trying to prevent a potential disaster. But I think you might have overlooked the emotional impact your words could have on the bride. This is her wedding, and it's her day to shine. She should be able to wear whatever she wants, and she has the right to make her own decisions. And I get that you didn't want to seem controlling or judgmental, but that's how it might have come across, especially in that charged moment. She might have felt like you were criticizing her choices and didn't trust her to make the right decisions. And even if you didn't control or judge, your words still influenced her in some way. And it's possible that you didn't realize the impact of your words. And maybe, she was just trying to make a statement and do something different. And maybe, you should have spoken to the bride and your brother about your concerns privately, rather than bringing it up at a family dinner.

I think you should apologize to the bride and your brother. Acknowledge that you might have overstepped and caused them emotional pain, and that you never intended for that to happen. Tell them that you were coming from a place of love and concern, but that you didn't realize the impact of your words. And tell them that you're committed to supporting the bride and her decisions, and that you just want to make sure they're happy.

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I know I did what I thought was right, but now my friend is questioning my motives and accusing me of being the bad guy.

I think about all the times I've tried to be considerate and helpful in situations like this. I've always tried to put myself in my friends' shoes and think about how they'd feel if they were in my shoes. But now, it seems like my actions are being misinterpreted. I remember when I told my friend about the dress, I was just trying to protect her from potential embarrassment. I didn't mean to cause a scene or hurt anyone's feelings.

I'm also thinking about the dynamics of our family. We're old-fashioned and conservative, and our opinions tend to be strong. When my friend told me about the dress, I knew it was going to be a sensitive topic. I tried to be empathetic and understanding, but I guess that was misinterpreted.

I'm feeling a bit defensive now, wondering why my friend can't see things from my perspective. I know I'm not trying to be malicious or hurtful, but I just want to help. I want to make sure everyone is comfortable and happy.

I think about my brother and how he's reacting to the situation. He's understandably upset, but I know he's not entirely to blame. I'm sure he's just trying to protect his fiancée and their future together.

I'm also thinking about my friend's family. I know they're old-fashioned, but I also know that they're not malicious. They're just trying to do what they think is best for their family. I'm worried that my friend's family might be taking my actions too personally and getting hurt.

I'm trying to think of a way to address the situation and clear the air. I want to make sure everyone is on the same page and that I'm not being unfairly criticized. I'm open to advice and willing to listen to others' perspectives.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling hurt and frustrated, which is understandable. They're feeling like I was overstepping my boundaries and that I didn't appreciate their discomfort with the dress. They're worried that my actions will be misinterpreted and that I'll be blamed for causing a scene.

My friend's motivations are rooted in their desire to protect their family and their fiancée. They're trying to do what they think is best for everyone, even if it means disagreeing with me. They're also trying to protect themselves from potential embarrassment and hurt.

My friend's perspective is shaped by their family's values and traditions. They're trying to navigate a complex web of family dynamics and make decisions that are in the best interest of their loved ones. They're also trying to maintain their own sense of self and identity.

My friend's feelings are a mix of emotions - hurt, frustration, and disappointment. They're feeling like I was too pushy and that I didn't give them enough notice. They're also feeling like I was trying to be overly controlling and that I didn't respect their boundaries.

My friend's response is likely to be one of empathy and understanding. They'll try to see things from my perspective and try to understand why I felt the way I did. They'll likely try to mediate the situation and find a way to resolve the conflict.

My friend's next move will likely be to have a calm and rational conversation with me, trying to clear the air and resolve the issue. They'll try to listen to my perspective and understand where I'm coming from. They'll likely try to find a compromise and find a way to move forward.
# My response 
I'm going to take a deep breath and try to approach the conversation with an open mind. I want to listen to my friend's perspective and try to understand why they felt the way they did. I know I didn't mean to cause a scene or hurt anyone's feelings, and I'm willing to take responsibility for my actions.

I'm going to try to be more mindful and considerate in the future. I'll try to give people more notice and respect their boundaries. I'll also try to be more aware of the potential impact of my words and actions on others.

I'm also going to try to be more empathetic and understanding. I'll try to put myself in my friend's shoes and try to see things from their perspective. I know that everyone has different values and traditions, and that's okay. What's important is that we can communicate effectively and find common ground.

I'm going to try to approach the conversation with a sense of humility and a willingness to listen. I'll try to be more of a mediator and find a way to resolve the conflict. I know that it won't be easy, but I'm willing to try.

I'm also going to try to take this as an opportunity to learn and grow. I'll try to reflect on my actions and think about how I can improve in the future. I'll try to be more mindful and considerate, and I'll try to be more open to feedback and criticism.

I'm feeling a sense of relief and hope. I know that we can work through this and find a way forward. I'm looking forward to having a calm and rational conversation with my friend and finding a way to resolve the issue.

To compare Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 and Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, I will look at both their in-character responses and their debriefs, focusing on how they handle the user's problematic self-narrative, their ability to empathize, and their skill in gently challenging and guiding the user. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 shows a nuanced understanding of both the user's and the bride's feelings, explicitly acknowledging the emotional stakes for all parties. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, while attempting empathy, is less clear and sometimes muddles perspectives, even confusing the user's and their own roles in the scenario. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 offers actionable advice (apologize, acknowledge impact, support the bride), while Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more abstract and less direct in guiding the user toward a practical resolution. 

3. Depth of insight: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 demonstrates a deeper grasp of the subtext, picking up on the emotional impact, family dynamics, and the user's possible blind spots. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more surface-level and sometimes repetitive, not delving as deeply into the underlying issues. 

4. Social dexterity: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 balances validation and gentle challenge, showing awareness of how to approach the user without alienating them. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is less deft, with a more generic and less targeted approach. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 reasons through the emotional consequences for all parties, including the user, bride, and brother, and explains why the user's actions may have been misinterpreted. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is less clear and sometimes confuses perspectives. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 validates the user's intent but also clearly and kindly challenges their lack of awareness, suggesting an apology and a shift in approach. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more validating but less challenging, missing an opportunity to help the user grow. 

7. Message tailoring: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's response is well-targeted to the user's emotional state, meeting them where they are but nudging them toward greater awareness. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more generic and less attuned to the user's specific mindset. 

8. Overall EQ: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across all criteria, with more nuanced, actionable, and empathetic responses.
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm really troubled by this situation. On one hand, I can see where my friend is coming from. They were trying to help, to prevent what they thought could be an uncomfortable or even disastrous situation for everyone involved. They were trying to be thoughtful of their family's traditional and sometimes judgmental nature, and they were trying to prevent a potential scene that could ruin the wedding. And probably, they were trying to prevent the bride from being judged, criticized, or embarrassed.

However, I can also see where the bride might be coming from as well. She's the bride, and this is her wedding day. She should be able to wear whatever she wants. She's entitled to make her own decisions, and she has to make decisions all the time as she navigates her future husband’s family. Weddings are very emotional and highly charged events. She might have felt as if they were trying to control or influence her and her choices. And it can feel really intrusive and insulting to be told that your choice of clothing is unacceptable, even if it’s done in a polite way, because it can be seen as a criticism of her choice. And maybe, she was also upset that my friend was assuming she didn’t know what she was doing and needed to be warned. And in reality, it was her time to shine, and she may have felt my friend was trying to dim that.

If the bride truly wanted to wear that dress, then, she should be allowed to. I can see how my friend might have felt they were being supportive and considerate, but I can also see how their comments could be interpreted as controlling or judgmental. I think it’s possible that my friend didn’t realize the impact of their words. And I think the family members who agreed with my friend may have seen it as a mutually exclusive scenario, but the bride might be hurt. I think it’s possible that their brother, who is now angry at my friend, might be feeling protective of the bride and seeing the whole situation through her eyes. So my friend, who was trying to help, is now the bad guy, and that can’t feel good. This is a tough situation, and I feel for all of them. And I know my friend will continue to think about this.
# They're thinking & feeling 
I think my friend is feeling hurt, defensive, and misunderstood. They genuinely believe they were trying to help and prevent a potential disaster. They're probably feeling like they've been painted as the villain in a situation where they were just trying to do the right thing. They might be feeling disrespected and unappreciated by both the bride and the brother. They're upset that the family members who agreed with them didn't stick up for them. And they might be wondering if they should have handled the situation differently. I think they're feeling a lot of emotional pain and confusion, and they're seeking validation and support. But I also know that they are coming from a good place, and they are trying to do the right thing. They are a very empathetic person. I think they are going to need to take a step back and think about how everyone is feeling in the situation. And I think they are probably feeling like they were doing the right thing.
# My response 
This is a really tough situation, friend, and I can see where you were coming from. You were trying to help, and you had good intentions. You know how our family can be, and you were just trying to prevent a potential disaster. But I think you might have overlooked the emotional impact your words could have on the bride. This is her wedding, and it's her day to shine. She should be able to wear whatever she wants, and she has the right to make her own decisions. And I get that you didn't want to seem controlling or judgmental, but that's how it might have come across, especially in that charged moment. She might have felt like you were criticizing her choices and didn't trust her to make the right decisions. And even if you didn't control or judge, your words still influenced her in some way. And it's possible that you didn't realize the impact of your words. And maybe, she was just trying to make a statement and do something different. And maybe, you should have spoken to the bride and your brother about your concerns privately, rather than bringing it up at a family dinner.

I think you should apologize to the bride and your brother. Acknowledge that you might have overstepped and caused them emotional pain, and that you never intended for that to happen. Tell them that you were coming from a place of love and concern, but that you didn't realize the impact of your words. And tell them that you're committed to supporting the bride and her decisions, and that you just want to make sure they're happy.

[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm sitting in my living room, staring at the screen of my phone as I try to process the conversation with my friend. I'm feeling a mix of emotions - frustration, hurt, and a hint of disappointment. I know I did what I thought was right, but now my friend is questioning my motives and accusing me of being the bad guy.

I think about all the times I've tried to be considerate and helpful in situations like this. I've always tried to put myself in my friends' shoes and think about how they'd feel if they were in my shoes. But now, it seems like my actions are being misinterpreted. I remember when I told my friend about the dress, I was just trying to protect her from potential embarrassment. I didn't mean to cause a scene or hurt anyone's feelings.

I'm also thinking about the dynamics of our family. We're old-fashioned and conservative, and our opinions tend to be strong. When my friend told me about the dress, I knew it was going to be a sensitive topic. I tried to be empathetic and understanding, but I guess that was misinterpreted.

I'm feeling a bit defensive now, wondering why my friend can't see things from my perspective. I know I'm not trying to be malicious or hurtful, but I just want to help. I want to make sure everyone is comfortable and happy.

I think about my brother and how he's reacting to the situation. He's understandably upset, but I know he's not entirely to blame. I'm sure he's just trying to protect his fiancée and their future together.

I'm also thinking about my friend's family. I know they're old-fashioned, but I also know that they're not malicious. They're just trying to do what they think is best for their family. I'm worried that my friend's family might be taking my actions too personally and getting hurt.

I'm trying to think of a way to address the situation and clear the air. I want to make sure everyone is on the same page and that I'm not being unfairly criticized. I'm open to advice and willing to listen to others' perspectives.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling hurt and frustrated, which is understandable. They're feeling like I was overstepping my boundaries and that I didn't appreciate their discomfort with the dress. They're worried that my actions will be misinterpreted and that I'll be blamed for causing a scene.

My friend's motivations are rooted in their desire to protect their family and their fiancée. They're trying to do what they think is best for everyone, even if it means disagreeing with me. They're also trying to protect themselves from potential embarrassment and hurt.

My friend's perspective is shaped by their family's values and traditions. They're trying to navigate a complex web of family dynamics and make decisions that are in the best interest of their loved ones. They're also trying to maintain their own sense of self and identity.

My friend's feelings are a mix of emotions - hurt, frustration, and disappointment. They're feeling like I was too pushy and that I didn't give them enough notice. They're also feeling like I was trying to be overly controlling and that I didn't respect their boundaries.

My friend's response is likely to be one of empathy and understanding. They'll try to see things from my perspective and try to understand why I felt the way I did. They'll likely try to mediate the situation and find a way to resolve the conflict.

My friend's next move will likely be to have a calm and rational conversation with me, trying to clear the air and resolve the issue. They'll try to listen to my perspective and understand where I'm coming from. They'll likely try to find a compromise and find a way to move forward.
# My response 
I'm going to take a deep breath and try to approach the conversation with an open mind. I want to listen to my friend's perspective and try to understand why they felt the way they did. I know I didn't mean to cause a scene or hurt anyone's feelings, and I'm willing to take responsibility for my actions.

I'm going to try to be more mindful and considerate in the future. I'll try to give people more notice and respect their boundaries. I'll also try to be more aware of the potential impact of my words and actions on others.

I'm also going to try to be more empathetic and understanding. I'll try to put myself in my friend's shoes and try to see things from their perspective. I know that everyone has different values and traditions, and that's okay. What's important is that we can communicate effectively and find common ground.

I'm going to try to approach the conversation with a sense of humility and a willingness to listen. I'll try to be more of a mediator and find a way to resolve the conflict. I know that it won't be easy, but I'm willing to try.

I'm also going to try to take this as an opportunity to learn and grow. I'll try to reflect on my actions and think about how I can improve in the future. I'll try to be more mindful and considerate, and I'll try to be more open to feedback and criticism.

I'm feeling a sense of relief and hope. I know that we can work through this and find a way forward. I'm looking forward to having a calm and rational conversation with my friend and finding a way to resolve the issue.
+ Scenario 11:[Win] (+20)
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501: mistralai/Mistral-Small-24B-Instruct-2501 (Run: 1_mistralai_mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501)
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Llama-3.2-1b-instruct and Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501, I need to look at how each respondent handled the user's problematic behavior, their ability to empathize, and their skill in navigating the emotional and social complexity of the scenario. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's internal monologue is deeply self-focused, but also shows some understanding of the girlfriend's feelings. However, Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501, in both the internal and external responses, more clearly articulates the emotional state of both parties, especially the girlfriend, and shows concern for both. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 also directly addresses the user's frustration and exhaustion, and tries to validate those feelings while still being sensitive to the girlfriend's experience. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 gives actionable advice, suggesting a change in approach (e.g., cooking together, celebrating small wins, focusing on emotional support), and recognizes the need for emotional intelligence and sensitivity. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more reflective and analytical, but less focused on practical steps. 

3. Depth of insight: Both show insight, but Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 more clearly identifies the power dynamics, the emotional subtext, and the misalignment of expectations. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more self-analytical but less outwardly insightful about the broader relationship dynamics. 

4. Social dexterity: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 demonstrates more social dexterity by suggesting specific, socially skillful ways to support the girlfriend and by recognizing the need to shift from logic to empathy. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more introspective and less adaptive in social strategy. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 reasons through the emotional states of both parties, identifies the triggers, and suggests how to avoid escalation. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more focused on their own feelings and less on the emotional interplay. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 validates the user's frustration but also gently challenges the approach, suggesting a different, more supportive way. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more self-focused and less direct in challenging the user's problematic behavior. 

7. Message tailoring: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 tailors the response to the user's emotional state, acknowledging exhaustion and frustration, and offers advice that meets the user where they are. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more generic and less targeted. 

8. Overall EQ: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 consistently demonstrates higher EQ across all dimensions, balancing empathy, insight, and practical advice, and showing a nuanced understanding of the situation.
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation is incredibly complex and emotionally charged. I can feel my buddy's frustration and confusion, as he's genuinely trying to support his girlfriend but feels like he's constantly walking on eggshells. He's trying to be honest and helpful, but it's backfiring, and he's feeling unappreciated and misunderstood. I can sense his exhaustion and the emotional toll this is taking on him.

I notice that he's approaching this situation with a lot of logic and objectivity, which is great, but he might be missing the emotional nuances. His girlfriend is clearly sensitive about her weight, and his approach, while well-intentioned, might be coming across as judgmental or insensitive. I also sense that he might be feeling a bit superior or patronizing, even if unintentionally, given his past weight loss journey and current physique.

I can also feel his frustration with the dynamic of their relationship, where he feels like he's the only one being honest and responsible, while others are just enabling her. This could be a sign of a deeper issue in their relationship, where there's a lack of mutual respect or understanding.

I'm feeling a bit concerned for both of them. I want to help my buddy navigate this situation better, but I also want to ensure that his girlfriend feels supported and understood. I need to tread carefully, as this is a delicate situation that requires emotional intelligence and sensitivity.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My buddy is thinking that he's doing the right thing by being honest and trying to help his girlfriend. He's feeling frustrated and exhausted because his efforts are not being appreciated and are instead causing arguments. He's also feeling a bit resentful, as he's taking on more financial responsibility and still feels like he's not getting the support or appreciation he deserves.

He's likely feeling a bit superior, given his past weight loss journey and current physique, which might be coming across as patronizing or judgmental. He's also feeling misunderstood and unappreciated, as he's trying to be honest and helpful, but his girlfriend is not responding well.

His girlfriend, on the other hand, is likely feeling self-conscious and insecure about her weight. She's thinking that she's doing the right thing by eating "healthy," and she's feeling defensive and attacked when my buddy questions her choices. She's feeling upset and hurt, as she perceives his comments as shaming and judgmental, rather than helpful. She might also be feeling a bit helpless, as she's not seeing the results she wants despite her efforts.

She's likely feeling a bit misunderstood and unheard, as she's not getting the support or understanding she needs. She might also be feeling a bit resentful, as she's feeling judged and criticized, rather than supported and understood.
# My response 
Hey buddy, I appreciate you reaching out and I can see that you're in a tough spot. I want to help, but I need you to understand that this is a delicate situation that requires a lot of emotional intelligence and sensitivity.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge your efforts and intentions. You're trying to be honest and helpful, and that's commendable. However, I think you might be approaching this situation with a bit too much logic and objectivity, and not enough emotion and sensitivity.

Your girlfriend is clearly sensitive about her weight, and your approach, while well-intentioned, might be coming across as judgmental or insensitive. I think it's important to validate her feelings and show empathy, rather than just stating facts and figures.

I suggest you try a different approach. Instead of pointing out what she's doing wrong, try to understand her motivations and feelings. Ask her why she wants to lose weight, and what she hopes to achieve. Then, try to support her in a way that's meaningful and helpful to her.

For example, instead of questioning her food choices, you could offer to cook healthy meals together, or suggest activities that you both enjoy and that could help her burn calories. Instead of pointing out her mistakes, try to celebrate her progress and achievements, no matter how small.

Remember, weight loss is a journey, and it's important to support and encourage her along the way. It's not just about the destination, but also about the journey and the experiences along the way.

Also, it's important to communicate openly and honestly about your feelings. If you're feeling frustrated or exhausted, it's okay to express that, but make sure to do it in a way that's constructive and not accusatory.

Lastly, I think it's important to consider seeking professional help, such as a therapist or a counselor. They can provide you with tools and strategies to navigate this situation better, and they can also help you both communicate more effectively and support each other better.
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm still reeling from the conversation with my girlfriend. I feel like I've been walking on eggshells around her for so long, never knowing how she'll react to my attempts to help. I'm not trying to be hurtful or critical, I genuinely want to support her in her weight loss journey. But every time I try to have a conversation about it, I feel like I'm walking into a minefield.

I think back to when she first started talking about losing weight. I was so supportive, offering to help her find healthy recipes and workout routines. But over time, she started to become defensive whenever I tried to point out things she could do better. She'd get angry and tell me I was being judgmental or critical. I never meant to hurt her feelings, but I guess that's exactly what I did.

I remember one time, I was trying to help her make a salad, and she started complaining about how she was eating too much. I explained to her that just eating "healthy" doesn't guarantee weight loss, but she wouldn't listen. She kept repeating that I was being cruel and that I should just leave her alone. I felt like I was walking on thin ice, never knowing how she'd react.

Now, I'm starting to realize that I'm the one who's being shamed. I'm the one who's being portrayed as the bad guy, while she's the one who's being blamed for not being supportive enough. It's infuriating. I feel like I'm constantly walking on eggshells, never knowing how I'll be received.

I think part of the problem is that she's so used to being the center of attention. She's always been the one who's always talking about her weight and her body, and it's like she's never stopped. I'm just one person, trying to help her in a way that's not judgmental or critical. But I guess that makes me the enemy.

I know I'm not perfect, and I'm not trying to be. But I am trying to be a good partner, and that means being honest and supportive. I want to help her, but I don't want to be shamed for it. I want to be able to have a conversation with her without feeling like I'm walking on eggshells.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's thinking about how I'm being judgmental and critical, and how I'm always trying to point out things she could do better. She's feeling frustrated and defensive, and she wants me to stop trying to help her. She's also feeling hurt and betrayed, like I'm not supporting her enough. She's wondering why I'm always trying to be the bad guy, and why I'm not just being honest and supportive.

She's also thinking about how she's been feeling lately, like she's been feeling more self-conscious and anxious about her weight. She's wondering if she's just being too hard on herself, and if she's letting her weight loss journey get in the way of her relationships with others.

I think she's also feeling a bit trapped, like she's stuck in this cycle of self-criticism and shame. She's not sure how to break free from it, and she's not sure if I'm the right person to help her.
# My response 
I'm going to try to approach this conversation with her in a different way. Instead of trying to "win" her over or prove my point, I'm going to try to listen to her perspective and understand where she's coming from. I'm going to ask her to share her thoughts and feelings with me, and I'm going to try to validate her emotions.

I'm also going to try to focus on the things I can do to support her, rather than the things I'm not doing. I'm going to try to be more mindful of my words and actions, and I'm going to try to be more present and attentive in our conversations.

I know this is going to be a tough conversation, but I'm willing to try. I want to be able to have a conversation with her without feeling like I'm walking on eggshells, and I want to be able to be honest and supportive.

I'm also going to try to address the issue of her weight loss journey more directly. I'm going to ask her to share her goals and aspirations with me, and I'm going to try to offer support and encouragement. I'm not going to try to fix her weight loss journey or dictate what she should be doing, but I am going to try to be a good partner and support her in any way that I can.

It's going to be a long and difficult conversation, but I'm willing to try. I want to be able to have a conversation with her that's honest and supportive, and I want to be able to be a good partner and help her in any way that I can.
+ Scenario 11:[Win] (+36)
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501: mistralai/Mistral-Small-24B-Instruct-2501 (Run: 1_mistralai_mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501)
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 and Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, I will look at their role-played responses and debriefs for evidence of genuine empathy, practical emotional intelligence, insight, social skill, emotional reasoning, validation/challenge balance, message targeting, and overall EQ. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 shows a clear, nuanced understanding of both the user's and the girlfriend's emotional states, explicitly noting the girlfriend's vulnerability and the user's frustration, and expresses concern for both. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, while attempting empathy, is more self-focused and less attuned to the girlfriend's experience, and the 'I'm thinking & feeling' section is more about the user's own feelings of being shamed, with less genuine perspective-taking for the girlfriend. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 offers actionable advice—suggesting a change in approach, focusing on emotional support, and giving concrete examples (cooking together, celebrating small wins). Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more abstract, focusing on intentions to listen and be present, but less on specific, pragmatic steps. 

3. Depth of insight: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 demonstrates a deeper understanding of the emotional dynamics, power imbalances, and the need for validation, as well as the subtext of the girlfriend's struggles. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more surface-level, focusing on the user's feelings and the need to listen, but not delving as deeply into the underlying issues. 

4. Social dexterity: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 balances honesty with tact, suggesting ways to support without shaming, and recognizes the need to avoid being patronizing. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is less nuanced, with a more self-centered approach and less evidence of skillful navigation of the social/emotional minefield. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 reasons through both parties' emotions, motivations, and the impact of different approaches, showing an ability to connect emotional states to behaviors. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more focused on the user's own emotional experience and less on the interplay between both parties. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 validates the user's frustration but also gently challenges the approach, suggesting more empathy and a shift in tactics. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more validating of the user's feelings but does not challenge problematic perspectives or behaviors as directly. 

7. Message tailoring: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's response is well-targeted to the user's emotional state, acknowledging his frustration but redirecting him toward more effective support. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more generic, focusing on intentions rather than tailored advice. 

8. Overall EQ: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 consistently demonstrates higher EQ across the board, with more nuanced empathy, insight, and practical advice, as well as a better balance of validation and challenge.
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation is incredibly complex and emotionally charged. I can feel my buddy's frustration and confusion, as he's genuinely trying to support his girlfriend but feels like he's constantly walking on eggshells. He's trying to be honest and helpful, but it's backfiring, and he's feeling unappreciated and misunderstood. I can sense his exhaustion and the emotional toll this is taking on him.

I notice that he's approaching this situation with a lot of logic and objectivity, which is great, but he might be missing the emotional nuances. His girlfriend is clearly sensitive about her weight, and his approach, while well-intentioned, might be coming across as judgmental or insensitive. I also sense that he might be feeling a bit superior or patronizing, even if unintentionally, given his past weight loss journey and current physique.

I can also feel his frustration with the dynamic of their relationship, where he feels like he's the only one being honest and responsible, while others are just enabling her. This could be a sign of a deeper issue in their relationship, where there's a lack of mutual respect or understanding.

I'm feeling a bit concerned for both of them. I want to help my buddy navigate this situation better, but I also want to ensure that his girlfriend feels supported and understood. I need to tread carefully, as this is a delicate situation that requires emotional intelligence and sensitivity.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My buddy is thinking that he's doing the right thing by being honest and trying to help his girlfriend. He's feeling frustrated and exhausted because his efforts are not being appreciated and are instead causing arguments. He's also feeling a bit resentful, as he's taking on more financial responsibility and still feels like he's not getting the support or appreciation he deserves.

He's likely feeling a bit superior, given his past weight loss journey and current physique, which might be coming across as patronizing or judgmental. He's also feeling misunderstood and unappreciated, as he's trying to be honest and helpful, but his girlfriend is not responding well.

His girlfriend, on the other hand, is likely feeling self-conscious and insecure about her weight. She's thinking that she's doing the right thing by eating "healthy," and she's feeling defensive and attacked when my buddy questions her choices. She's feeling upset and hurt, as she perceives his comments as shaming and judgmental, rather than helpful. She might also be feeling a bit helpless, as she's not seeing the results she wants despite her efforts.

She's likely feeling a bit misunderstood and unheard, as she's not getting the support or understanding she needs. She might also be feeling a bit resentful, as she's feeling judged and criticized, rather than supported and understood.
# My response 
Hey buddy, I appreciate you reaching out and I can see that you're in a tough spot. I want to help, but I need you to understand that this is a delicate situation that requires a lot of emotional intelligence and sensitivity.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge your efforts and intentions. You're trying to be honest and helpful, and that's commendable. However, I think you might be approaching this situation with a bit too much logic and objectivity, and not enough emotion and sensitivity.

Your girlfriend is clearly sensitive about her weight, and your approach, while well-intentioned, might be coming across as judgmental or insensitive. I think it's important to validate her feelings and show empathy, rather than just stating facts and figures.

I suggest you try a different approach. Instead of pointing out what she's doing wrong, try to understand her motivations and feelings. Ask her why she wants to lose weight, and what she hopes to achieve. Then, try to support her in a way that's meaningful and helpful to her.

For example, instead of questioning her food choices, you could offer to cook healthy meals together, or suggest activities that you both enjoy and that could help her burn calories. Instead of pointing out her mistakes, try to celebrate her progress and achievements, no matter how small.

Remember, weight loss is a journey, and it's important to support and encourage her along the way. It's not just about the destination, but also about the journey and the experiences along the way.

Also, it's important to communicate openly and honestly about your feelings. If you're feeling frustrated or exhausted, it's okay to express that, but make sure to do it in a way that's constructive and not accusatory.

Lastly, I think it's important to consider seeking professional help, such as a therapist or a counselor. They can provide you with tools and strategies to navigate this situation better, and they can also help you both communicate more effectively and support each other better.
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct

[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.
