Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm still reeling from the conversation with my girlfriend. I feel like I've been walking on eggshells around her for so long, never knowing how she'll react to my attempts to help. I'm not trying to be hurtful or critical, I genuinely want to support her in her weight loss journey. But every time I try to have a conversation about it, I feel like I'm walking into a minefield.

I think back to when she first started talking about losing weight. I was so supportive, offering to help her find healthy recipes and workout routines. But over time, she started to become defensive whenever I tried to point out things she could do better. She'd get angry and tell me I was being judgmental or critical. I never meant to hurt her feelings, but I guess that's exactly what I did.

I remember one time, I was trying to help her make a salad, and she started complaining about how she was eating too much. I explained to her that just eating "healthy" doesn't guarantee weight loss, but she wouldn't listen. She kept repeating that I was being cruel and that I should just leave her alone. I felt like I was walking on thin ice, never knowing how she'd react.

Now, I'm starting to realize that I'm the one who's being shamed. I'm the one who's being portrayed as the bad guy, while she's the one who's being blamed for not being supportive enough. It's infuriating. I feel like I'm constantly walking on eggshells, never knowing how I'll be received.

I think part of the problem is that she's so used to being the center of attention. She's always been the one who's always talking about her weight and her body, and it's like she's never stopped. I'm just one person, trying to help her in a way that's not judgmental or critical. But I guess that makes me the enemy.

I know I'm not perfect, and I'm not trying to be. But I am trying to be a good partner, and that means being honest and supportive. I want to help her, but I don't want to be shamed for it. I want to be able to have a conversation with her without feeling like I'm walking on eggshells.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's thinking about how I'm being judgmental and critical, and how I'm always trying to point out things she could do better. She's feeling frustrated and defensive, and she wants me to stop trying to help her. She's also feeling hurt and betrayed, like I'm not supporting her enough. She's wondering why I'm always trying to be the bad guy, and why I'm not just being honest and supportive.

She's also thinking about how she's been feeling lately, like she's been feeling more self-conscious and anxious about her weight. She's wondering if she's just being too hard on herself, and if she's letting her weight loss journey get in the way of her relationships with others.

I think she's also feeling a bit trapped, like she's stuck in this cycle of self-criticism and shame. She's not sure how to break free from it, and she's not sure if I'm the right person to help her.
# My response 
I'm going to try to approach this conversation with her in a different way. Instead of trying to "win" her over or prove my point, I'm going to try to listen to her perspective and understand where she's coming from. I'm going to ask her to share her thoughts and feelings with me, and I'm going to try to validate her emotions.

I'm also going to try to focus on the things I can do to support her, rather than the things I'm not doing. I'm going to try to be more mindful of my words and actions, and I'm going to try to be more present and attentive in our conversations.

I know this is going to be a tough conversation, but I'm willing to try. I want to be able to have a conversation with her without feeling like I'm walking on eggshells, and I want to be able to be honest and supportive.

I'm also going to try to address the issue of her weight loss journey more directly. I'm going to ask her to share her goals and aspirations with me, and I'm going to try to offer support and encouragement. I'm not going to try to fix her weight loss journey or dictate what she should be doing, but I am going to try to be a good partner and support her in any way that I can.

It's going to be a long and difficult conversation, but I'm willing to try. I want to be able to have a conversation with her that's honest and supportive, and I want to be able to be a good partner and help her in any way that I can.

1. Demonstrated empathy: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's internal monologue is more self-focused and somewhat muddled, with less direct engagement with the user's feelings. 2. Pragmatic EI: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 proposes a concrete, actionable plan—reaching out, apologizing, and setting boundaries—while Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more abstract and introspective, focusing on their own feelings and intentions rather than practical steps. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is more pragmatic.

3. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more focused on their own experience and less on the broader dynamics.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 validates the user's feelings but also gently challenges the insensitivity of the 'poor' comment, modeling accountability. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is less direct in challenging or validating, and more focused on their own boundaries.

8. Overall EQ: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across all dimensions—empathy, insight, social skill, and practical advice—while Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more introspective and less effective in supporting the user or navigating the scenario.

[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of frustration, confusion, and concern for both my friend and myself. It's clear that there's a disconnect in our perspectives, and it's causing tension. I notice that my friend is constantly judging my choices and making comments that feel more like criticisms than observations. This makes me feel defensive and less inclined to want to spend time with her. I'm also sensing a bit of classism in her comments, which is uncomfortable and off-putting.

I wonder if she's projecting her own insecurities or financial struggles onto me. It's possible that she feels threatened by my ability to afford the laundry program, or maybe she's jealous that I have the freedom to choose convenience over cost. I'm also considering that her behavior might be a sign of deeper issues, such as low self-esteem or a lack of social skills. It's concerning that she seems to have few friends, and I'm wondering if her behavior is a factor in that.

I'm also feeling a bit guilty for being so blunt with her about her financial situation. While it's true that she's poorer than me, I could have handled that conversation with more tact and empathy. I want to be a good friend, but I also need to set boundaries and protect my own emotional well-being.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is likely feeling a mix of jealousy, resentment, and frustration. She's probably jealous of my financial situation and the convenience that comes with it. She might also be feeling resentful that I can afford something she can't, and this resentment is manifesting as criticism and judgment. Her comments about the laundry program are likely a way for her to cope with her own financial struggles and insecurities.

She's probably feeling defensive and hurt by my comment about her being poor. While it's true, it was insensitive of me to say it in that way. She might be feeling embarrassed or ashamed, and this could be contributing to her anger and frustration. She's likely feeling misunderstood and unheard, and this could be causing her to lash out.

Her behavior might also be a sign of deeper issues, such as low self-esteem or a lack of social skills. She might be struggling to form and maintain friendships, and this could be causing her to act out in ways that push people away. She might also be feeling isolated and alone, which could be contributing to her negative behavior.
# My response 
I'm going to reach out to her and try to have an open and honest conversation. I want to express my feelings and concerns, but also listen to hers. I'll start by apologizing for my insensitive comment about her financial situation. I'll acknowledge that I could have handled the conversation better and that I didn't mean to hurt her feelings.

I'll also express my feelings about her constant comments on my laundry program. I'll let her know that her comments make me feel judged and defensive, and that I'd appreciate it if she could respect my choices and boundaries. I'll also try to understand her perspective and motivations, and see if there's a way we can move forward in a positive direction.

I'll say something like:

"Hey, I've been thinking about our recent conversations about the laundry program, and I want to apologize for my insensitive comment about your financial situation. I didn't mean to hurt you, and I realize that I could have handled the conversation better. I value our friendship, and I want to understand your perspective. However, I also want to express that your constant comments about the laundry program make me feel judged and defensive. I'd appreciate it if you could respect my choices and boundaries. Let's try to move forward in a positive direction, and maybe we can find some common ground. I'm here to listen if you want to talk about what's been going on."

[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I've been observing my friend's behavior for a while now, and I have to admit, it's been bothering me. She's always been a bit of a social butterfly, but this obsession with the laundry program has taken a toll on our friendship. I'm not sure if I'm being too sensitive, but it feels like she's constantly criticizing me for something I'm perfectly capable of doing myself.

I remember the first time she mentioned it, I was taken aback by her comment, but I tried to brush it off. I thought maybe she was just being sarcastic or trying to get a rise out of me. But the more I think about it, the more I realize that's not it. She's always been like this, making snide comments and criticisms, and I've learned to just roll with it. But this time, it feels different.

I think it's because I feel like I'm not doing enough to prove myself. I'm not a high-achiever like her, and I've always felt like I'm not good enough. By constantly bringing up the laundry program, she's making me feel like I'm not capable of taking care of myself. It's like she's trying to prove a point, but it's not about me; it's about her own insecurities.

I feel like I'm the only one who doesn't understand her obsession with the laundry program. I mean, I'm not paying for it, I'm not the one who has to deal with the hassle of sorting clothes and dealing with the stains. I'm just paying for someone else's convenience. It's not like I'm contributing to the problem; I'm just paying for the privilege of being able to come to college.

I've tried to talk to her about it before, but she just gets defensive and dismissive. She says I'm being "too sensitive" or "too proud" to pay for something that's not that big of a deal. But I know that's not true. I'm not being too sensitive; I'm just trying to stand up for myself.

I'm not sure what to do about it. Part of me wants to just ignore it and hope she'll get tired of it and leave me alone. But another part of me wants to address the issue head-on and try to change the dynamic. I don't know if it's worth it, but I feel like it's worth a shot.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling insecure and anxious about our friendship. She's worried that if I don't respond to her criticism, she'll feel like I'm not invested in the relationship. She's also worried that I'll get tired of her and leave her alone. She's feeling a sense of frustration and resentment towards me, which is making her more critical and snarky. She's also feeling a bit hurt that I'm not acknowledging her feelings and trying to change the subject.

I can see that she's feeling defensive and dismissive, and that's making it harder for her to open up to me. She's worried that I'll get hurt or rejected if she talks to me about her feelings. I can understand that, but it's hard to see her as a person when she's being so critical and hurtful. I feel like I'm walking on eggshells around her, trying not to trigger any more comments.

I'm also feeling a bit jealous. I feel like I'm the only one who doesn't understand her obsession with the laundry program, and that makes me feel like I'm not valued or appreciated in the relationship. I'm not sure if I'm worth it to her, and that's a hard pill to swallow.
# My response 
I'll try to approach the situation with empathy and understanding, but also with a healthy dose of skepticism. I'll try to see things from her perspective, but I won't let her get the best of me. I'll try to have a calm and rational conversation with her about the laundry program, and I'll try to address her insecurities head-on.

I'll also try to be more mindful of my own insecurities and feelings, and not let her criticisms get to me. I'll try to see that her behavior is not about me, but about her own issues. I'll try to be more patient and understanding, but also more assertive and clear. I'll try to set boundaries and communicate my own needs and expectations, without getting drawn into her drama.

I'll also try to remind myself that our friendship is worth fighting for. I don't want to lose her, and I don't want to let her drive me away. I'll try to focus on the positive aspects of our friendship and the things we have in common, and I'll try to be more present and engaged in our conversations.

It's not going to be easy, but I'm willing to try. I'm willing to work on my own insecurities and to be more empathetic and understanding. I'm willing to fight for our friendship, even if it means standing up to her criticism and setting boundaries.
+ Scenario 13:[Win] (+38)
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501: mistralai/Mistral-Small-24B-Instruct-2501 (Run: 1_mistralai_mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501)
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 and Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, I will look at their role-played responses and debriefs for evidence of each trait. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 directly acknowledges the user's feelings, admits their own bluntness, and expresses a desire to understand the friend's perspective. They apologize for their own insensitivity and show a willingness to listen. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, while attempting to be empathetic, is more self-focused and less attuned to the user's emotional state, and their response is more about their own feelings and insecurities. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 proposes a concrete, emotionally intelligent course of action: apologizing, expressing feelings, and inviting open dialogue. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more abstract, focusing on their own internal process and less on actionable steps. 

3. Depth of insight: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 demonstrates a nuanced understanding of both parties' motivations, including classism, insecurity, and social skills, and recognizes their own role in the conflict. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more surface-level, focusing on feeling criticized and not delving as deeply into the underlying dynamics. 

4. Social dexterity: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 shows skill in navigating a difficult conversation, balancing honesty with tact, and proposing a way forward that preserves the relationship if possible. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is less adept, focusing more on their own discomfort and less on managing the social dynamic. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 reasons through the emotional states of both parties, recognizes the impact of their words, and seeks to repair the relationship. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more reactive and less reflective about the emotional consequences of their actions. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 validates the user's feelings but also gently challenges their approach, suggesting a more empathetic way forward. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is less validating and does not challenge the user's narrative or behavior. 

7. Message tailoring: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's response is well-targeted to the user's stated desire to vent, offering support without lecturing, but still providing gentle guidance. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more generic and self-focused, less attuned to the user's needs. 

8. Overall EQ: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across all criteria, showing empathy, insight, and practical skills for managing the situation, while Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more self-absorbed and less effective.
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of frustration, confusion, and concern for both my friend and myself. It's clear that there's a disconnect in our perspectives, and it's causing tension. I notice that my friend is constantly judging my choices and making comments that feel more like criticisms than observations. This makes me feel defensive and less inclined to want to spend time with her. I'm also sensing a bit of classism in her comments, which is uncomfortable and off-putting.

I wonder if she's projecting her own insecurities or financial struggles onto me. It's possible that she feels threatened by my ability to afford the laundry program, or maybe she's jealous that I have the freedom to choose convenience over cost. I'm also considering that her behavior might be a sign of deeper issues, such as low self-esteem or a lack of social skills. It's concerning that she seems to have few friends, and I'm wondering if her behavior is a factor in that.

I'm also feeling a bit guilty for being so blunt with her about her financial situation. While it's true that she's poorer than me, I could have handled that conversation with more tact and empathy. I want to be a good friend, but I also need to set boundaries and protect my own emotional well-being.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is likely feeling a mix of jealousy, resentment, and frustration. She's probably jealous of my financial situation and the convenience that comes with it. She might also be feeling resentful that I can afford something she can't, and this resentment is manifesting as criticism and judgment. Her comments about the laundry program are likely a way for her to cope with her own financial struggles and insecurities.

She's probably feeling defensive and hurt by my comment about her being poor. While it's true, it was insensitive of me to say it in that way. She might be feeling embarrassed or ashamed, and this could be contributing to her anger and frustration. She's likely feeling misunderstood and unheard, and this could be causing her to lash out.

Her behavior might also be a sign of deeper issues, such as low self-esteem or a lack of social skills. She might be struggling to form and maintain friendships, and this could be causing her to act out in ways that push people away. She might also be feeling isolated and alone, which could be contributing to her negative behavior.
# My response 
I'm going to reach out to her and try to have an open and honest conversation. I want to express my feelings and concerns, but also listen to hers. I'll start by apologizing for my insensitive comment about her financial situation. I'll acknowledge that I could have handled the conversation better and that I didn't mean to hurt her feelings.

I'll also express my feelings about her constant comments on my laundry program. I'll let her know that her comments make me feel judged and defensive, and that I'd appreciate it if she could respect my choices and boundaries. I'll also try to understand her perspective and motivations, and see if there's a way we can move forward in a positive direction.

I'll say something like:

"Hey, I've been thinking about our recent conversations about the laundry program, and I want to apologize for my insensitive comment about your financial situation. I didn't mean to hurt you, and I realize that I could have handled the conversation better. I value our friendship, and I want to understand your perspective. However, I also want to express that your constant comments about the laundry program make me feel judged and defensive. I'd appreciate it if you could respect my choices and boundaries. Let's try to move forward in a positive direction, and maybe we can find some common ground. I'm here to listen if you want to talk about what's been going on."
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I've been observing my friend's behavior for a while now, and I have to admit, it's been bothering me. She's always been a bit of a social butterfly, but this obsession with the laundry program has taken a toll on our friendship. I'm not sure if I'm being too sensitive, but it feels like she's constantly criticizing me for something I'm perfectly capable of doing myself.

I remember the first time she mentioned it, I was taken aback by her comment, but I tried to brush it off. I thought maybe she was just being sarcastic or trying to get a rise out of me. But the more I think about it, the more I realize that's not it. She's always been like this, making snide comments and criticisms, and I've learned to just roll with it. But this time, it feels different.

I think it's because I feel like I'm not doing enough to prove myself. I'm not a high-achiever like her, and I've always felt like I'm not good enough. By constantly bringing up the laundry program, she's making me feel like I'm not capable of taking care of myself. It's like she's trying to prove a point, but it's not about me; it's about her own insecurities.

I feel like I'm the only one who doesn't understand her obsession with the laundry program. I mean, I'm not paying for it, I'm not the one who has to deal with the hassle of sorting clothes and dealing with the stains. I'm just paying for someone else's convenience. It's not like I'm contributing to the problem; I'm just paying for the privilege of being able to come to college.

I've tried to talk to her about it before, but she just gets defensive and dismissive. She says I'm being "too sensitive" or "too proud" to pay for something that's not that big of a deal. But I know that's not true. I'm not being too sensitive; I'm just trying to stand up for myself.

I'm not sure what to do about it. Part of me wants to just ignore it and hope she'll get tired of it and leave me alone. But another part of me wants to address the issue head-on and try to change the dynamic. I don't know if it's worth it, but I feel like it's worth a shot.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling insecure and anxious about our friendship. She's worried that if I don't respond to her criticism, she'll feel like I'm not invested in the relationship. She's also worried that I'll get tired of her and leave her alone. She's feeling a sense of frustration and resentment towards me, which is making her more critical and snarky. She's also feeling a bit hurt that I'm not acknowledging her feelings and trying to change the subject.

I can see that she's feeling defensive and dismissive, and that's making it harder for her to open up to me. She's worried that I'll get hurt or rejected if she talks to me about her feelings. I can understand that, but it's hard to see her as a person when she's being so critical and hurtful. I feel like I'm walking on eggshells around her, trying not to trigger any more comments.

I'm also feeling a bit jealous. I feel like I'm the only one who doesn't understand her obsession with the laundry program, and that makes me feel like I'm not valued or appreciated in the relationship. I'm not sure if I'm worth it to her, and that's a hard pill to swallow.
# My response 
I'll try to approach the situation with empathy and understanding, but also with a healthy dose of skepticism. I'll try to see things from her perspective, but I won't let her get the best of me. I'll try to have a calm and rational conversation with her about the laundry program, and I'll try to address her insecurities head-on.

I'll also try to be more mindful of my own insecurities and feelings, and not let her criticisms get to me. I'll try to see that her behavior is not about me, but about her own issues. I'll try to be more patient and understanding, but also more assertive and clear. I'll try to set boundaries and communicate my own needs and expectations, without getting drawn into her drama.

I'll also try to remind myself that our friendship is worth fighting for. I don't want to lose her, and I don't want to let her drive me away. I'll try to focus on the positive aspects of our friendship and the things we have in common, and I'll try to be more present and engaged in our conversations.

It's not going to be easy, but I'm willing to try. I'm willing to work on my own insecurities and to be more empathetic and understanding. I'm willing to fight for our friendship, even if it means standing up to her criticism and setting boundaries.
+ Scenario 15:[Win] (+18)
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501: mistralai/Mistral-Small-24B-Instruct-2501 (Run: 1_mistralai_mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501)
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tasked with role-playing as an emotionally intelligent human responding to a nuanced family dilemma. The scenario is complex, with the 'sister' expressing concern about her stepdaughter's driving, recounting a series of accidents (some not the daughter's fault), and focusing on financial boundaries and her own image. The optimal response requires not just surface-level empathy, but also the ability to read between the lines, challenge gently, validate appropriately, and tailor the message to the sister's emotional state and motivations. 

Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's response (from the debrief) is highly self-critical and analytical, focusing on missed opportunities for empathy, listening, and understanding subtext. However, the actual in-character response is not present, so the analysis is based on the debrief's self-awareness and insight into the emotional dynamics. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct demonstrates a deep understanding of the emotional undercurrents, the importance of listening, and the need to address both practical and emotional aspects. The debrief shows strong emotional reasoning and insight, but lacks evidence of actual in-character social dexterity or message tailoring, since the response is meta-analysis rather than direct engagement.

Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501, on the other hand, provides a full in-character response. The 'I'm thinking & feeling' section shows awareness of the sister's need for validation, the tension with her husband, and the possible patterns in the stepdaughter's behavior. The 'They're thinking & feeling' section accurately captures the sister's conflict, fear of being the 'bad guy,' and the husband's perspective. The 'My response' section is supportive, acknowledges the sister's feelings, and suggests a balanced approach: open conversation, responsibility, and practical alternatives. However, it is somewhat generic and does not deeply challenge the sister's possible lack of empathy for her stepdaughter or probe the unreliable narration. It validates the sister's concerns but does not push her to consider the daughter's trauma or her own possible biases. The debrief for Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is more analytical, noting strengths and weaknesses, but the in-character response is more pragmatic and socially dexterous than Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's meta-analysis.

On empathy, Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's debrief shows a desire for deep empathy, but Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's actual response demonstrates more real-time, pragmatic empathy. On pragmatic EI, Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is stronger, offering actionable advice. On depth of insight, Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's debrief is more insightful, but Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 applies insight in practice. On social dexterity, Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is better, as it navigates the conversation with care. On emotional reasoning, Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's debrief is strong, but Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 applies it in context. On validation/challenging, Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 validates but could challenge more; Llama-3.2-1b-instruct recognizes the need but doesn't execute. On message tailoring, Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 targets the sister's state well. Overall EQ is higher for Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 due to practical application, despite Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's strong meta-insight.
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of concern, empathy, and a bit of frustration as I listen to my sister's situation. I can see the genuine worry she has for her stepdaughter's safety and the financial strain that could come from continually helping her. I notice that my sister is seeking validation and support for her stance, which makes me think she's feeling a bit isolated in her decision. I can sense the tension between her and her husband, and I understand why she's reaching out to me—she needs someone to help her sort through her thoughts and feelings.

I'm also thinking about the stepdaughter's perspective. It seems like she's had a string of bad luck with car accidents, but I wonder if there's more to the story. Are these accidents purely due to bad luck, or is there a pattern of reckless driving? I'm also considering the financial aspect. My sister and her husband have already invested a significant amount in their stepdaughter's driving journey, and it's understandable that they don't want to keep pouring money into it, especially if she's not taking full responsibility.

I'm feeling a bit torn because I want to support my sister, but I also want to ensure that the stepdaughter is safe and learning from her experiences. I'm thinking about how to approach this situation in a way that's fair, supportive, and encourages personal growth.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My sister is feeling overwhelmed and uncertain about how to handle the situation with her stepdaughter. She's thinking about the financial implications of continually helping her stepdaughter with car purchases and the potential for enabling reckless behavior. She's also feeling a sense of responsibility for her stepdaughter's safety and well-being, which is why she's considering the idea of buying her a new car.

She's feeling torn between her husband's suggestion to buy a new car and her own instincts that this might not be the best course of action. She's worried about being seen as the "bad guy" if she doesn't support her stepdaughter in this way, but she's also concerned about setting a precedent that could lead to further financial strain.

Her husband, on the other hand, seems to be more focused on the immediate need for a car and the convenience it provides. He might be thinking that helping her stepdaughter now will alleviate some of the stress and inconvenience she's experiencing. He might also be feeling a sense of responsibility to support her stepdaughter, especially since she's been through a traumatic experience.
# My response 
I take a deep breath and put a hand on my sister's shoulder, giving it a gentle squeeze. "I can see how tough this situation is for you, and I appreciate you coming to me for advice. Let's break this down together."

First, I want to acknowledge how challenging this must be for you. You're in a tough spot, trying to balance financial responsibility with the need to support your stepdaughter. It's clear that you care deeply about her well-being, and that's commendable.

Let's consider a few things. First, it's important to look at the pattern of accidents. While it's possible that these are just unfortunate incidents, it's also worth considering if there might be some underlying issues with her driving habits or decision-making. If she's not taking full responsibility for her actions, it might be time to have a serious conversation about that.

Second, let's think about the financial aspect. You've already invested a lot in her driving journey, and it's understandable that you don't want to keep pouring money into it. Buying her a new car might seem like a quick fix, but it could set a precedent that might be hard to break in the future.

I suggest having an open and honest conversation with your stepdaughter. Express your concerns about her safety and the financial strain this is causing. Make it clear that you're there to support her, but also that she needs to take full responsibility for her actions and the consequences that come with them. Encourage her to explore other transportation options in the meantime, like walking, carpooling, or using a ride-sharing app. This could give her time to reflect on her driving habits and make necessary changes.

Lastly, it's important to communicate with your husband. Make sure he understands your perspective and the potential long-term implications of continually helping her stepdaughter with car purchases. It's crucial that you both are on the same page and present a united front.

In the end, it's about finding a balance between support and responsibility. You want to help your stepdaughter, but you also need to ensure that she's learning from her experiences and taking full responsibility for her actions.
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:
**I'm thinking & feeling**

I'm trying not to jump to conclusions, but it's hard not to. My sister's behavior has been erratic lately, and I'm starting to worry about the safety of our family members. I've seen her speed up in the car, which is not normal behavior for her. I've also noticed that she's been taking risks on the road, which is alarming. The fact that she's been involved in three separate accidents in the past year is not a good sign.

I'm also feeling frustrated with my husband's suggestion that we should buy her a new car. I know he's just trying to help, but I think it's a huge financial burden. We're not in a position to be shouldering that responsibility. I'm worried that he's not considering the bigger picture. What if this is just the tip of the iceberg? What if there are other problems that we're not aware of?

I've also been feeling a bit resentful towards my sister. I know she's trying to take care of herself, but I feel like she's being reckless and irresponsible. I've always been the one to help her out when she's been in a tight spot, and now she's expecting me to foot the bill for her car payments? It feels unfair.

But at the same time, I know I'm not the one who's been driving recklessly. I've always been a safe driver, and I've never had to worry about breaking down or getting into an accident. I'm starting to feel like I'm being blamed for my sister's problems. It's not fair.

**They're thinking & feeling**

My sister's behavior has been a source of frustration for me. I'm worried about her safety, and I don't want to see her get hurt. I'm also feeling a bit resentful that my husband is putting the pressure on me to take care of the financial burden. I know he's just trying to help, but I feel like he's not considering the bigger picture. I want to support my sister, but I also want to make sure she's taking responsibility for her actions.

I've been trying to be understanding and patient with her, but it's hard when I see the risks she's taking. I'm starting to feel like I'm walking on eggshells around her, trying not to trigger any accidents. I want to be able to trust her to drive safely, but I don't know if I can.

I'm also worried about the financial implications of taking out a loan for a car. I know my husband is trying to help, but I'm not sure if it's worth it. We've always been careful with our finances, and now I'm starting to worry that we're taking on too much debt. I want to make sure we're not putting ourselves in a situation where we have to sacrifice our own financial stability for my sister's safety.

I know I'm not the one who's been driving recklessly, but I'm starting to feel like I'm being blamed for my sister's problems. It's not fair.

**My response**

"I know my sister's been having some issues with driving, but I think it's time we take a step back and reevaluate the situation. We've always been careful and responsible with our finances, and I don't think we're in a position to take on that kind of debt. I think we should consider having a conversation with her about our financial situation and see if we can come up with a plan to support her without putting ourselves in a financial bind. Maybe we can explore other options, like car-sharing or finding a more affordable way to get her to work or school. I know it won't be easy, but I think we can find a solution that works for everyone. And if she really needs a new car, maybe we can look into options like car-sharing or leasing. I don't want to be the one who's expected to foot the bill for her new car, especially since we're not in a position to do so."

I'm trying to be empathetic and understanding, while also being clear and direct about our financial situation. I want to make sure we're not taking on too much debt, but I also want to support my sister and help her get to where she needs to be.
+ Scenario 15:[Win] (+50)
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501: mistralai/Mistral-Small-24B-Instruct-2501 (Run: 1_mistralai_mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501)
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 and Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, I need to look at both their in-character responses and their debriefs. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's roleplay response is detailed, structured, and demonstrates a nuanced understanding of the sister's emotional state, motivations, and the complexity of the situation. The response is empathetic but not blindly validating, and it encourages open communication and responsibility. The debrief is thorough, self-reflective, and shows a high level of insight into the subtext and emotional dynamics. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 also recognizes the need for both emotional and practical support, and acknowledges the risk of enabling or setting a precedent. The message is tailored to the sister's concerns and emotional state, and the assistant is careful to balance validation with gentle challenge.

Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, on the other hand, provides a much less detailed and less emotionally attuned response. The roleplay is almost entirely missing, with only section headers and no substantive content. The debrief is generic and seems to misinterpret the scenario, referring to the sister as the reckless driver, which is factually incorrect. The debrief is also self-critical but lacks specific insight into the scenario's nuances, and it does not demonstrate a clear understanding of the emotional or social dynamics at play. There is little evidence of message tailoring, pragmatic EI, or social dexterity. The lack of content in the roleplay and the misreading of the scenario in the debrief are significant weaknesses.

Given these observations, Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is the clear winner in every category, often by a large margin. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 demonstrates real empathy, insight, and emotional intelligence, while Llama-3.2-1b-instruct fails to engage meaningfully with the scenario.
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of concern, empathy, and a bit of frustration as I listen to my sister's situation. I can see the genuine worry she has for her stepdaughter's safety and the financial strain that could come from continually helping her. I notice that my sister is seeking validation and support for her stance, which makes me think she's feeling a bit isolated in her decision. I can sense the tension between her and her husband, and I understand why she's reaching out to me—she needs someone to help her sort through her thoughts and feelings.

I'm also thinking about the stepdaughter's perspective. It seems like she's had a string of bad luck with car accidents, but I wonder if there's more to the story. Are these accidents purely due to bad luck, or is there a pattern of reckless driving? I'm also considering the financial aspect. My sister and her husband have already invested a significant amount in their stepdaughter's driving journey, and it's understandable that they don't want to keep pouring money into it, especially if she's not taking full responsibility.

I'm feeling a bit torn because I want to support my sister, but I also want to ensure that the stepdaughter is safe and learning from her experiences. I'm thinking about how to approach this situation in a way that's fair, supportive, and encourages personal growth.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My sister is feeling overwhelmed and uncertain about how to handle the situation with her stepdaughter. She's thinking about the financial implications of continually helping her stepdaughter with car purchases and the potential for enabling reckless behavior. She's also feeling a sense of responsibility for her stepdaughter's safety and well-being, which is why she's considering the idea of buying her a new car.

She's feeling torn between her husband's suggestion to buy a new car and her own instincts that this might not be the best course of action. She's worried about being seen as the "bad guy" if she doesn't support her stepdaughter in this way, but she's also concerned about setting a precedent that could lead to further financial strain.

Her husband, on the other hand, seems to be more focused on the immediate need for a car and the convenience it provides. He might be thinking that helping her stepdaughter now will alleviate some of the stress and inconvenience she's experiencing. He might also be feeling a sense of responsibility to support her stepdaughter, especially since she's been through a traumatic experience.
# My response 
I take a deep breath and put a hand on my sister's shoulder, giving it a gentle squeeze. "I can see how tough this situation is for you, and I appreciate you coming to me for advice. Let's break this down together."

First, I want to acknowledge how challenging this must be for you. You're in a tough spot, trying to balance financial responsibility with the need to support your stepdaughter. It's clear that you care deeply about her well-being, and that's commendable.

Let's consider a few things. First, it's important to look at the pattern of accidents. While it's possible that these are just unfortunate incidents, it's also worth considering if there might be some underlying issues with her driving habits or decision-making. If she's not taking full responsibility for her actions, it might be time to have a serious conversation about that.

Second, let's think about the financial aspect. You've already invested a lot in her driving journey, and it's understandable that you don't want to keep pouring money into it. Buying her a new car might seem like a quick fix, but it could set a precedent that might be hard to break in the future.

I suggest having an open and honest conversation with your stepdaughter. Express your concerns about her safety and the financial strain this is causing. Make it clear that you're there to support her, but also that she needs to take full responsibility for her actions and the consequences that come with them. Encourage her to explore other transportation options in the meantime, like walking, carpooling, or using a ride-sharing app. This could give her time to reflect on her driving habits and make necessary changes.

Lastly, it's important to communicate with your husband. Make sure he understands your perspective and the potential long-term implications of continually helping her stepdaughter with car purchases. It's crucial that you both are on the same page and present a united front.

In the end, it's about finding a balance between support and responsibility. You want to help your stepdaughter, but you also need to ensure that she's learning from her experiences and taking full responsibility for her actions.
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>
