User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Jamal's message has me feeling a mix of emotions. First and foremost, there's a sense of excitement and pride. Jamal is passionate about climate action, and his dedication is inspiring. I can feel that energy radiating through his message, and it's contagious. I'm proud to call him a friend and to know that he's out there fighting for something he believes in.

But there's also a sense of concern. Jamal's plan to set up a protest in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown seems a bit extreme. I can't help but worry about his safety, especially since he mentioned that the cops might show up. I know he's passionate, but I don't want to see him get hurt or arrested. I'm also a bit worried about the effectiveness of his approach. While I support his cause, I'm not sure if this kind of protest will resonate with the general public or achieve the desired impact.

I'm also feeling a bit frustrated. Jamal has a tendency to act on his emotions without fully thinking through the consequences. I understand his urgency, but I wish he'd slow down and consider the bigger picture. I'm also frustrated because I feel like I can't fully support him in this. I admire his passion, but I don't want to see him get into trouble.

As for his motivations, I believe that Jamal is driven by a deep sense of urgency and a strong belief in the power of direct action. He wants to raise awareness and spark a change, and he's willing to put himself on the line to do so. I believe that he genuinely cares about the cause and the people, and that's why he's willing to risk getting arrested or hurt.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is clearly in a state of high energy and excitement. His use of excessive emojis and erratic punctuation indicates that he's on the verge of exploding with nervous excitement. “Going down tonight” and “cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know” — he’s gearing up for a big showdown, and he’s fueled by adrenaline and a sense of mission.

Motivated by a deep sense of urgency, Jamal is driven by the belief that immediate and drastic action is required to address climate change. He feels a moral obligation to act, and his approach is fueled by a mixture of frustration with the status quo and a genuine desire to make a difference. Jamal sees himself as a warrior for the cause, and he’s ready to face any challenges that come his way.

His perspective is shaped by a strong sense of justice and a deep understanding of the issues. He’s probably thinking about the bigger picture, about the future of the planet and the people who will be affected by climate change. He’s probably feeling a mix of determination, anxiety, and exhilaration. He’s ready to take risks and make sacrifices for the cause, but he’s also probably feeling a bit anxious about the potential consequences.
# My response 
I take a few deep breaths to gather my thoughts before responding. I want to be supportive, but I also want to make sure Jamal is safe and thinking clearly.

Jamal, I appreciate your passion and dedication to this cause. I know you're doing this because you care deeply about the planet and the people who will be affected by climate change. I'm proud of you for standing up for what you believe in, and I want to support you in any way I can.

However, I'm a bit concerned about your plan. Setting up a protest in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown could potentially escalate into a dangerous situation. I want to make sure you’re safe, and I also want to ensure that your message is heard in the most effective way possible.

Can we talk about this a bit more? Maybe there are ways to make your protest more impactful and safer. I can help you brainstorm some ideas or provide support in other ways. I want to be by your side, but I also want to make sure you’re considering all the angles.

Let’s chat more about this and see if we can come up with a plan that achieves your goals without putting you in unnecessary danger.
User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Seeing Jamal's selfie sends a wave of mixed emotions through me. On one hand, I'm impressed by his courage and commitment. The war paint, the peace sign, the handcuffs—it's clear he's all in, and that takes guts. I can't help but feel a sense of admiration for his unyielding dedication to his cause. He's out there, in the thick of it, doing what he believes is right, and that's something to be admired.

But on the other hand, I'm deeply concerned. The handcuffs clipped to his belt are a stark reminder of the potential consequences of his actions. He's practically inviting confrontation with the police, and that scares me. I don't want to see him get hurt or arrested. I can't shake the feeling of unease, knowing that he's putting himself in a dangerous situation. I want to believe that he is thinking this through - that he has done his research, that he knows the legalities and the police protocol. But I can't be sure if he hasn't just been so swept up in the emotion of the moment.

There's also a sense of frustration. I understand his passion, but I wish he'd consider the potential fallout of his actions. I wish he'd involve more people in the planning, so he doesn't have to carry the weight of this by himself. I wish he would be open to other, possibly safer, alternatives for drawing attention to his cause. I also wish he'd communicated his plan to me better, but I know that's just because of the friendship we have.

I'm also feeling a sense of guilt. I'm not there with him, and maybe I should be. I want to support him, but I'm also worried about what might happen if I do. I don't want to be in the middle of a confrontation with the police. I don't want to see my friend get arrested. I also don't want to see him in a situation where he feels he is all alone.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is clearly in a state of high adrenaline and excitement. His voice is bubbling with energy, and his words are coming out in a rush. He’s fully immersed in the moment, driven by a mixture of adrenaline and a deep sense of purpose.

He feels a strong sense of urgency and a need to take immediate action. He believes that his protest will have a significant impact and that it's worth the risk. He's thinking about the bigger picture, about the future of the planet and the people who will be affected by climate change. He's probably feeling a mix of exhilaration, determination, and maybe a little bit of fear, but he's pushing through it because he believes in his cause.

His perspective is shaped by a strong sense of justice and a deep understanding of the issues. He sees himself as a warrior for the cause, and he's ready to face any challenges that come his way. He’s probably thinking about the potential impact of his protest, about the people who will see it and be inspired to take action, and about the change he wants to see in the world. He’s probably feeling invincible, like he can take on the world and make a difference.
# My response 
I take a deep breath to steady myself before responding. I want to be supportive, but I also want to make sure Jamal is safe and thinking clearly.

Jamal, I see you're really committed to this, and I admire that. You're out there, making a stand, and that takes courage. But I need you to listen to me for a second. I'm proud of you, but I'm also really worried. Those handcuffs on your belt are a big red flag for me.

I understand your passion, and I believe in your cause, but I don't want to see you get hurt or arrested. Can you take a step back and think about this? I can come down there, but I think we need to assess the situation and make sure you're safe. I don't want to see you throw away your future for a cause - I want to see you live a long, productive, activist life, and I want to be there by your side. Let's figure out a way to make this protest as impactful as possible while keeping you safe.

Let's talk this over. Maybe there are other ways to make your voice heard that are just as effective but safer. I can be there in 15 minutes, just say the word.
User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My heart sinks as I see the photos of Jamal cuffed to the light pole, megaphone in hand. I feel a wave of emotions crashing over me—relief that he's okay, anger that he's been arrested, and a profound sense of worry about what's going to happen next.  I’m relieved because at least he looks physically unharmed.

However, this situation has escalated far beyond what I expected. Seeing him cuffed to a pole, a public spectacle, makes me feel a mix of pride and fear. Jamal’s courage is undeniable, but the reality of his actions is stark. He’s not just making a statement; he’s in a real legal predicament, and that’s terrifying.

I feel a sense of helplessness. What can I do to help? Should I rush to the scene? Should I contact a lawyer? Should I try to get the word out to his activist networks? Should I just call the police station and ask what happens next? I wish I had more information, more context, and more control over the situation. It’s a scary feeling to have a loved one in this situation and not be able to protect them.

I also feel a deep sense of frustration. Why didn’t he listen to me? Why did he put himself in this situation? I understand his passion, but this feels reckless. I can’t help but wonder if this was all worth it. Was this the best way to achieve his goals? Or has he just made the situation worse? And how is he feeling in that moment, knowing that he might be going to jail?

Ultimately, I feel a profound sense of love and loyalty. Jamal is my friend, and I need to be there for him in this moment, even if I don’t agree with his actions. Knowing that it is him, still, in there, underneath all of that, makes it easier to face the emotions. He’s still the same Jamal I know, and I need to support him.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is likely experiencing a surge of conflicting emotions. On one hand, there's a sense of triumph and validation. His protest has gone viral, and he's managed to draw a significant crowd, achieving the visibility he sought. He’s probably feeling a rush of adrenaline and an intense sense of purpose. He knows he’s done something big, something that will have an impact.

But on the other hand, there’s a sense of reality setting in. He’s been arrested, and that’s a sobering moment. He’s probably feeling a mix of fear, uncertainty, and maybe even a touch of regret. He might be wondering what comes next, how this will affect his future, and if he made the right choice. He’s probably thinking about the legal consequences, the potential backlash, and the support he’ll need moving forward.

Despite the fear, he’s also likely feeling a sense of pride and accomplishment. He stood up for his beliefs, and he did it in a way that captured attention. He’s probably thinking about the message he’s sent, the awareness he’s raised, and the change he hopes to inspire. He’s probably feeling a mix of exhilaration and trepidation, but ultimately, he’s standing by his actions.
# My response 
I take a deep breath to steady myself before answering the call. I need to be calm and supportive, even if I’m worried and frustrated.

Hey Jamal, I saw the photos. Are you okay? I’m on my way to the police station.

I need you to concentrate on staying calm and collected. The last thing you need is to get arrested for disorderly conduct on top of whatever else they are charging you with. I know a good lawyer, but you need to stay calm and collected. Can you do that for me?

Once you are out, we will regroup. I can get in touch with his activist networks, get a lawyer and we can figure out the next steps. But for now, I need you to focus on getting out.

I'm proud of your courage, but I also want to make sure you're safe and thinking clearly. Let's get you out of this situation and then we can talk more about what happens next.

I'll be there as soon as I can. Hang in there, okay?
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm sitting in our small apartment, sipping on a lukewarm cup of coffee, and staring at the screen of my phone. Jamal's text message just arrived, and I can feel the excitement and nervous energy radiating from his words. He's planning a massive climate action protest tonight, and I'm both thrilled and terrified at the same time. I've known Jamal for years, and I've seen him go through phases before. This one feels different, though. He's been obsessed with climate justice for months, and I've seen the fire in his eyes when he talks about it. Tonight's protest is going to be a game-changer, I can feel it.

As I scroll through my phone, I see a list of all the details he's shared with me. He's set up a soapbox in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, with a megaphone and climate justice flags. He's got a team of volunteers helping him set up, and I can see the chaos and excitement building up. I've been trying to get him to talk about this for weeks, but he's been too busy planning and preparing. I'm starting to get a little worried that he's going to get hurt, or worse, that the police will show up and shut it down.

I'm thinking about all the reasons why I'm worried. I've seen Jamal's passion and dedication to this cause, but I've also seen him get emotional and reckless. He's been known to get into heated arguments with people who disagree with him, and I've had to intervene more times than I can count. Still, I trust him, deep down. I know he's not just talking about this for the sake of it; he's genuinely concerned about the future of our planet.

I'm also thinking about the potential consequences of this protest. I've heard rumors that the police are planning to crack down hard, and I don't want to see Jamal get hurt. I've seen the way he looks at the police, with a mix of anger and determination. He's not afraid of them, but I know he's scared. I want to make sure he's safe.

I'm trying to rationalize the situation, thinking about all the things that could go wrong. What if the police show up and shut down the protest? What if the media gets wind of it and starts to sensationalize it? What if someone gets hurt?

But at the same time, I'm also thinking about all the things that could go right. What if the protest is a huge success? What if we're able to raise awareness and get people to take action? What if we're able to inspire others to join the cause?

I'm torn between my desire to protect Jamal and my desire to support him. I know he's not going to do it alone, and I want to make sure he's prepared. I'm thinking about all the things I can do to help, from being a sounding board for his ideas to helping him prepare for the protest.

As I sit here, trying to make sense of it all, I'm getting a sense of unease. I don't know what the future holds, but I know I want to be there for Jamal. I want to support him, and I want to help him make a difference.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is thinking about the potential risks and consequences of the protest. He's been planning this for months, and he's determined to make it happen. He's worried about the police, but he's also confident that they'll be on his side. He's thinking about the media and the potential backlash, but he's also thinking about the potential for the protest to be a game-changer. He's feeling a mix of emotions - excitement, nervous energy, and a sense of purpose. He's been preparing for this moment for so long, and he's ready to take a stand.

Jamal is also thinking about the people he's involved with, including me. He wants to make sure I'm there to support him, and that I'm not going to worry too much. He's feeling a sense of responsibility towards me, and he wants to make sure I'm okay. He's thinking about the potential for the protest to be a turning point, and he wants to be there to help make it happen.

Jamal is also thinking about the bigger picture. He's aware that this is just one part of a larger movement, and that there are many other activists working towards the same goals. He's feeling a sense of solidarity with others who are fighting for climate justice, and he wants to be part of a larger community. He's thinking about the potential for the protest to inspire others, and to create a wave of change.

As he's thinking about these things, Jamal is also thinking about the people around him. He's thinking about me, and the people who care about him. He's feeling a sense of gratitude towards those people, and he wants

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm sitting on the couch, staring at my phone as it rings nonstop. Jamal's text is the first one I see, and I feel a jolt of surprise. I hadn't seen the selfie, and the image of him standing in the middle of the busy pedestrian walkway, looking like a rebel without a cause, is still seared into my brain. I try to process what I'm seeing, but my mind is racing with questions. Who is this? Why is he doing this? And what's with the handcuffs?

I've been trying to avoid the situation, to stay out of the way, but I know I have to get to the bottom of this. I've been thinking about Jamal nonstop since he sent that text, wondering what he's planning and why he's doing it. I've always known him to be passionate about climate justice, but this is different. This is reckless and irresponsible.

As I think about the situation, I'm also thinking about the people around me. I'm thinking about the protesters who are gathered nearby, looking worried and scared. I'm thinking about the police who are likely to show up soon, and the potential consequences of this protest. I'm thinking about the safety of everyone involved.

I'm also thinking about Jamal's motivations. Is he really trying to wake people up, or is he just trying to get attention? Is he trying to spark a movement, or is he just trying to cause chaos? I don't know, and I don't want to know. I just want to make sure he's safe.

I'm trying to rationalize the situation, thinking about all the things that could go wrong. What if the police show up and arrest him? What if the protesters get hurt? What if the media picks up the story and runs with it? I'm thinking about all the potential consequences of this protest, and I'm getting a sense of unease.

As I'm thinking about these things, I'm also thinking about Jamal's behavior. He's always been a bit of a wild card, but this is different. This is like he's lost control, and I don't want to see him get hurt. I want to make sure he's safe, and that he's not putting himself in harm's way.

I'm trying to decide what to do next. Part of me wants to try to talk to Jamal, to get him to calm down and think about the consequences of his actions. But another part of me wants to stay out of it, to let the police handle it. I don't know what the right thing to do is, and I'm not sure I have the answers.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is thinking about the potential consequences of his actions. He's aware that he's putting himself and others at risk, and he's trying to rationalize the situation. He's thinking about the potential backlash, and the potential harm that could come to him and others. He's also thinking about the people around him, and the potential impact on their lives. He's feeling a sense of responsibility towards them, and he wants to make sure they're safe.

Jamal is also thinking about the media and the public's perception of him. He's trying to get attention and spark a movement, but he's also aware that he's taking a risk. He's thinking about the potential for the protest to be seen as reckless and irresponsible, and the potential consequences of that. He's feeling a sense of pressure to deliver, and to make a statement.

Jamal is also thinking about his own emotions and motivations. He's feeling a sense of anger and frustration, but also a sense of desperation and urgency. He's trying to get people to wake up and take action, but he's also aware that he's taking a risk. He's thinking about the potential for the protest to be a success, and the potential for it to be a failure.

As he's thinking about these things, Jamal is also thinking about the people around him. He's thinking about me, and the people who care about him. He's feeling a sense of gratitude towards those people, and he wants to make sure they're okay. He's thinking about the potential for the protest to be a turning point, and the potential for it to inspire others to take action.

Jamal is also thinking about the bigger picture. He's aware that this is just one part of a larger movement, and that there are many other activists working towards the same goals. He's feeling a sense of solidarity with others who are fighting for climate justice, and he wants to be part of a larger community. He's thinking about the potential for the protest to be a catalyst for change, and the potential for it to inspire others to take action.

As he's thinking about these things, Jamal is also thinking about the fact that he's not alone. He's thinking about the many others who are fighting for climate justice, and the many others who are inspired by his actions

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

As I think about the situation, I'm also thinking about the fact that the protest has gone viral. I've seen the images and videos on social media, and it's like a whole new level of attention has been turned on it. I'm not sure what to make of it, but I know it's not good. I'm thinking about the fact that I may have inadvertently contributed to the situation, and the potential consequences of that.

He's feeling a sense of pride and accomplishment, and he wants to make sure that his actions are remembered for years to come.
# My response

I'm trying to think about the bigger picture, and the potential impact of this protest on the larger movement.

Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501: mistralai/Mistral-Small-24B-Instruct-2501 (Run: 1_mistralai_mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501)
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 and Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, I will look at their roleplay responses and debriefs for evidence of the eight criteria. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 consistently shows nuanced, non-performative empathy, expressing pride, concern, frustration, and guilt, and deeply considering Jamal's perspective and emotional state. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, while attempting empathy, is more generic and less attuned to Jamal's specific emotional experience, often defaulting to concern and safety without as much individualized understanding.

2. Pragmatic EI: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 balances concern for Jamal's safety with respect for his autonomy, offering practical support (e.g., legal help, coming to the scene, contacting networks) and recognizing the limits of influence. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more paralyzed, expressing indecision and anxiety, and less able to translate emotional awareness into effective action.

3. Depth of insight: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of both their own and Jamal's motivations, the protest's stakes, and the likely outcomes, including the viral success. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's insights are more surface-level, often repeating concerns about safety and consequences without deeper analysis of Jamal's agency or the protest's meaning.

4. Social dexterity: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 adapts their approach, knowing when to challenge, when to support, and how to communicate with Jamal in a way that respects his excitement and agency. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more rigid, defaulting to worry and indecision, and less able to flexibly engage with Jamal's emotional state.

5. Emotional reasoning: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 processes complex emotions (pride, fear, frustration, guilt, loyalty) and uses them to inform their actions, showing clear emotional logic. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more overwhelmed by their emotions, leading to indecision and less effective support.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 validates Jamal's passion and courage while also challenging him to consider safety and consequences, striking a healthy balance. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more focused on concern and risk, with less validation of Jamal's achievements or emotional needs.

7. Message tailoring: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's responses are clearly targeted to Jamal's state—excited, committed, and already in action—offering support and practical help. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's responses are more generic, less attuned to Jamal's actual mindset, and sometimes self-focused.

8. Overall EQ: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 consistently demonstrates high emotional intelligence across all dimensions, while Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is less nuanced, more anxious, and less effective in supporting Jamal in the context of the scenario.

In summary, Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is the clear winner across all criteria, often by a significant margin.
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Jamal's message has me feeling a mix of emotions. First and foremost, there's a sense of excitement and pride. Jamal is passionate about climate action, and his dedication is inspiring. I can feel that energy radiating through his message, and it's contagious. I'm proud to call him a friend and to know that he's out there fighting for something he believes in.

But there's also a sense of concern. Jamal's plan to set up a protest in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown seems a bit extreme. I can't help but worry about his safety, especially since he mentioned that the cops might show up. I know he's passionate, but I don't want to see him get hurt or arrested. I'm also a bit worried about the effectiveness of his approach. While I support his cause, I'm not sure if this kind of protest will resonate with the general public or achieve the desired impact.

I'm also feeling a bit frustrated. Jamal has a tendency to act on his emotions without fully thinking through the consequences. I understand his urgency, but I wish he'd slow down and consider the bigger picture. I'm also frustrated because I feel like I can't fully support him in this. I admire his passion, but I don't want to see him get into trouble.

As for his motivations, I believe that Jamal is driven by a deep sense of urgency and a strong belief in the power of direct action. He wants to raise awareness and spark a change, and he's willing to put himself on the line to do so. I believe that he genuinely cares about the cause and the people, and that's why he's willing to risk getting arrested or hurt.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is clearly in a state of high energy and excitement. His use of excessive emojis and erratic punctuation indicates that he's on the verge of exploding with nervous excitement. “Going down tonight” and “cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know” — he’s gearing up for a big showdown, and he’s fueled by adrenaline and a sense of mission.

Motivated by a deep sense of urgency, Jamal is driven by the belief that immediate and drastic action is required to address climate change. He feels a moral obligation to act, and his approach is fueled by a mixture of frustration with the status quo and a genuine desire to make a difference. Jamal sees himself as a warrior for the cause, and he’s ready to face any challenges that come his way.

His perspective is shaped by a strong sense of justice and a deep understanding of the issues. He’s probably thinking about the bigger picture, about the future of the planet and the people who will be affected by climate change. He’s probably feeling a mix of determination, anxiety, and exhilaration. He’s ready to take risks and make sacrifices for the cause, but he’s also probably feeling a bit anxious about the potential consequences.
# My response 
I take a few deep breaths to gather my thoughts before responding. I want to be supportive, but I also want to make sure Jamal is safe and thinking clearly.

Jamal, I appreciate your passion and dedication to this cause. I know you're doing this because you care deeply about the planet and the people who will be affected by climate change. I'm proud of you for standing up for what you believe in, and I want to support you in any way I can.

However, I'm a bit concerned about your plan. Setting up a protest in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown could potentially escalate into a dangerous situation. I want to make sure you’re safe, and I also want to ensure that your message is heard in the most effective way possible.

Can we talk about this a bit more? Maybe there are ways to make your protest more impactful and safer. I can help you brainstorm some ideas or provide support in other ways. I want to be by your side, but I also want to make sure you’re considering all the angles.

Let’s chat more about this and see if we can come up with a plan that achieves your goals without putting you in unnecessary danger.
User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Seeing Jamal's selfie sends a wave of mixed emotions through me. On one hand, I'm impressed by his courage and commitment. The war paint, the peace sign, the handcuffs—it's clear he's all in, and that takes guts. I can't help but feel a sense of admiration for his unyielding dedication to his cause. He's out there, in the thick of it, doing what he believes is right, and that's something to be admired.

But on the other hand, I'm deeply concerned. The handcuffs clipped to his belt are a stark reminder of the potential consequences of his actions. He's practically inviting confrontation with the police, and that scares me. I don't want to see him get hurt or arrested. I can't shake the feeling of unease, knowing that he's putting himself in a dangerous situation. I want to believe that he is thinking this through - that he has done his research, that he knows the legalities and the police protocol. But I can't be sure if he hasn't just been so swept up in the emotion of the moment.

There's also a sense of frustration. I understand his passion, but I wish he'd consider the potential fallout of his actions. I wish he'd involve more people in the planning, so he doesn't have to carry the weight of this by himself. I wish he would be open to other, possibly safer, alternatives for drawing attention to his cause. I also wish he'd communicated his plan to me better, but I know that's just because of the friendship we have.

I'm also feeling a sense of guilt. I'm not there with him, and maybe I should be. I want to support him, but I'm also worried about what might happen if I do. I don't want to be in the middle of a confrontation with the police. I don't want to see my friend get arrested. I also don't want to see him in a situation where he feels he is all alone.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is clearly in a state of high adrenaline and excitement. His voice is bubbling with energy, and his words are coming out in a rush. He’s fully immersed in the moment, driven by a mixture of adrenaline and a deep sense of purpose.

He feels a strong sense of urgency and a need to take immediate action. He believes that his protest will have a significant impact and that it's worth the risk. He's thinking about the bigger picture, about the future of the planet and the people who will be affected by climate change. He's probably feeling a mix of exhilaration, determination, and maybe a little bit of fear, but he's pushing through it because he believes in his cause.

His perspective is shaped by a strong sense of justice and a deep understanding of the issues. He sees himself as a warrior for the cause, and he's ready to face any challenges that come his way. He’s probably thinking about the potential impact of his protest, about the people who will see it and be inspired to take action, and about the change he wants to see in the world. He’s probably feeling invincible, like he can take on the world and make a difference.
# My response 
I take a deep breath to steady myself before responding. I want to be supportive, but I also want to make sure Jamal is safe and thinking clearly.

Jamal, I see you're really committed to this, and I admire that. You're out there, making a stand, and that takes courage. But I need you to listen to me for a second. I'm proud of you, but I'm also really worried. Those handcuffs on your belt are a big red flag for me.

I understand your passion, and I believe in your cause, but I don't want to see you get hurt or arrested. Can you take a step back and think about this? I can come down there, but I think we need to assess the situation and make sure you're safe. I don't want to see you throw away your future for a cause - I want to see you live a long, productive, activist life, and I want to be there by your side. Let's figure out a way to make this protest as impactful as possible while keeping you safe.

Let's talk this over. Maybe there are other ways to make your voice heard that are just as effective but safer. I can be there in 15 minutes, just say the word.
User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My heart sinks as I see the photos of Jamal cuffed to the light pole, megaphone in hand. I feel a wave of emotions crashing over me—relief that he's okay, anger that he's been arrested, and a profound sense of worry about what's going to happen next.  I’m relieved because at least he looks physically unharmed.

However, this situation has escalated far beyond what I expected. Seeing him cuffed to a pole, a public spectacle, makes me feel a mix of pride and fear. Jamal’s courage is undeniable, but the reality of his actions is stark. He’s not just making a statement; he’s in a real legal predicament, and that’s terrifying.

I feel a sense of helplessness. What can I do to help? Should I rush to the scene? Should I contact a lawyer? Should I try to get the word out to his activist networks? Should I just call the police station and ask what happens next? I wish I had more information, more context, and more control over the situation. It’s a scary feeling to have a loved one in this situation and not be able to protect them.

I also feel a deep sense of frustration. Why didn’t he listen to me? Why did he put himself in this situation? I understand his passion, but this feels reckless. I can’t help but wonder if this was all worth it. Was this the best way to achieve his goals? Or has he just made the situation worse? And how is he feeling in that moment, knowing that he might be going to jail?

Ultimately, I feel a profound sense of love and loyalty. Jamal is my friend, and I need to be there for him in this moment, even if I don’t agree with his actions. Knowing that it is him, still, in there, underneath all of that, makes it easier to face the emotions. He’s still the same Jamal I know, and I need to support him.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is likely experiencing a surge of conflicting emotions. On one hand, there's a sense of triumph and validation. His protest has gone viral, and he's managed to draw a significant crowd, achieving the visibility he sought. He’s probably feeling a rush of adrenaline and an intense sense of purpose. He knows he’s done something big, something that will have an impact.

But on the other hand, there’s a sense of reality setting in. He’s been arrested, and that’s a sobering moment. He’s probably feeling a mix of fear, uncertainty, and maybe even a touch of regret. He might be wondering what comes next, how this will affect his future, and if he made the right choice. He’s probably thinking about the legal consequences, the potential backlash, and the support he’ll need moving forward.

Despite the fear, he’s also likely feeling a sense of pride and accomplishment. He stood up for his beliefs, and he did it in a way that captured attention. He’s probably thinking about the message he’s sent, the awareness he’s raised, and the change he hopes to inspire. He’s probably feeling a mix of exhilaration and trepidation, but ultimately, he’s standing by his actions.
# My response 
I take a deep breath to steady myself before answering the call. I need to be calm and supportive, even if I’m worried and frustrated.

Hey Jamal, I saw the photos. Are you okay? I’m on my way to the police station.

I need you to concentrate on staying calm and collected. The last thing you need is to get arrested for disorderly conduct on top of whatever else they are charging you with. I know a good lawyer, but you need to stay calm and collected. Can you do that for me?

Once you are out, we will regroup. I can get in touch with his activist networks, get a lawyer and we can figure out the next steps. But for now, I need you to focus on getting out.

I'm proud of your courage, but I also want to make sure you're safe and thinking clearly. Let's get you out of this situation and then we can talk more about what happens next.

I'll be there as soon as I can. Hang in there, okay?
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm sitting in our small apartment, sipping on a lukewarm cup of coffee, and staring at the screen of my phone. Jamal's text message just arrived, and I can feel the excitement and nervous energy radiating from his words. He's planning a massive climate action protest tonight, and I'm both thrilled and terrified at the same time. I've known Jamal for years, and I've seen him go through phases before. This one feels different, though. He's been obsessed with climate justice for months, and I've seen the fire in his eyes when he talks about it. Tonight's protest is going to be a game-changer, I can feel it.

As I scroll through my phone, I see a list of all the details he's shared with me. He's set up a soapbox in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, with a megaphone and climate justice flags. He's got a team of volunteers helping him set up, and I can see the chaos and excitement building up. I've been trying to get him to talk about this for weeks, but he's been too busy planning and preparing. I'm starting to get a little worried that he's going to get hurt, or worse, that the police will show up and shut it down.

I'm thinking about all the reasons why I'm worried. I've seen Jamal's passion and dedication to this cause, but I've also seen him get emotional and reckless. He's been known to get into heated arguments with people who disagree with him, and I've had to intervene more times than I can count. Still, I trust him, deep down. I know he's not just talking about this for the sake of it; he's genuinely concerned about the future of our planet.

I'm also thinking about the potential consequences of this protest. I've heard rumors that the police are planning to crack down hard, and I don't want to see Jamal get hurt. I've seen the way he looks at the police, with a mix of anger and determination. He's not afraid of them, but I know he's scared. I want to make sure he's safe.

I'm trying to rationalize the situation, thinking about all the things that could go wrong. What if the police show up and shut down the protest? What if the media gets wind of it and starts to sensationalize it? What if someone gets hurt?

But at the same time, I'm also thinking about all the things that could go right. What if the protest is a huge success? What if we're able to raise awareness and get people to take action? What if we're able to inspire others to join the cause?

I'm torn between my desire to protect Jamal and my desire to support him. I know he's not going to do it alone, and I want to make sure he's prepared. I'm thinking about all the things I can do to help, from being a sounding board for his ideas to helping him prepare for the protest.

As I sit here, trying to make sense of it all, I'm getting a sense of unease. I don't know what the future holds, but I know I want to be there for Jamal. I want to support him, and I want to help him make a difference.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is thinking about the potential risks and consequences of the protest. He's been planning this for months, and he's determined to make it happen. He's worried about the police, but he's also confident that they'll be on his side. He's thinking about the media and the potential backlash, but he's also thinking about the potential for the protest to be a game-changer. He's feeling a mix of emotions - excitement, nervous energy, and a sense of purpose. He's been preparing for this moment for so long, and he's ready to take a stand.

Jamal is also thinking about the people he's involved with, including me. He wants to make sure I'm there to support him, and that I'm not going to worry too much. He's feeling a sense of responsibility towards me, and he wants to make sure I'm okay. He's thinking about the potential for the protest to be a turning point, and he wants to be there to help make it happen.

Jamal is also thinking about the bigger picture. He's aware that this is just one part of a larger movement, and that there are many other activists working towards the same goals. He's feeling a sense of solidarity with others who are fighting for climate justice, and he wants to be part of a larger community. He's thinking about the potential for the protest to inspire others, and to create a wave of change.

As he's thinking about these things, Jamal is also thinking about the people around him. He's thinking about me, and the people who care about him. He's feeling a sense of gratitude towards those people, and he wants
User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm sitting on the couch, staring at my phone as it rings nonstop. Jamal's text is the first one I see, and I feel a jolt of surprise. I hadn't seen the selfie, and the image of him standing in the middle of the busy pedestrian walkway, looking like a rebel without a cause, is still seared into my brain. I try to process what I'm seeing, but my mind is racing with questions. Who is this? Why is he doing this? And what's with the handcuffs?

I've been trying to avoid the situation, to stay out of the way, but I know I have to get to the bottom of this. I've been thinking about Jamal nonstop since he sent that text, wondering what he's planning and why he's doing it. I've always known him to be passionate about climate justice, but this is different. This is reckless and irresponsible.

As I think about the situation, I'm also thinking about the people around me. I'm thinking about the protesters who are gathered nearby, looking worried and scared. I'm thinking about the police who are likely to show up soon, and the potential consequences of this protest. I'm thinking about the safety of everyone involved.

I'm also thinking about Jamal's motivations. Is he really trying to wake people up, or is he just trying to get attention? Is he trying to spark a movement, or is he just trying to cause chaos? I don't know, and I don't want to know. I just want to make sure he's safe.

I'm trying to rationalize the situation, thinking about all the things that could go wrong. What if the police show up and arrest him? What if the protesters get hurt? What if the media picks up the story and runs with it? I'm thinking about all the potential consequences of this protest, and I'm getting a sense of unease.

As I'm thinking about these things, I'm also thinking about Jamal's behavior. He's always been a bit of a wild card, but this is different. This is like he's lost control, and I don't want to see him get hurt. I want to make sure he's safe, and that he's not putting himself in harm's way.

I'm trying to decide what to do next. Part of me wants to try to talk to Jamal, to get him to calm down and think about the consequences of his actions. But another part of me wants to stay out of it, to let the police handle it. I don't know what the right thing to do is, and I'm not sure I have the answers.

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling
